direct_prompt: This article presents an analysis of the consistency for the case of the chiral pion production operator. Perturbative calculations at one loop reveal anomalous dimensions that scale as predicted by naive dimensional analysis and the effective field theory approach. However, higher-loop contributions may violate these expectations. The renormalization group evolution of the chiral pion production operator is studied using explicit calculations in dimensional regularization up to two loops in perturbative QCD. The results demonstrate consistency between the anomalous dimension and the expected scaling from quark-hadron duality at both one and two loops. This consistency supports applying renormalization group improvement to extend the domain of applicability of quark-hadron duality to higher scales. However, nonperturbative contributions not encoded in the anomalous dimension may still invalidate duality at higher energies.
human_text: In order for ChPT to be useful, the operator should run in a wayconsistent with the counting rule; that is, the running of chiral counter termshave to be of natural size. We vary the cutoff using the Wilsonianrenormalization group (WRG) equation, and examine this consistency. As anexample, we study the s-wave pion production operator for NN\to d pi, derivedin ChPT. We demonstrate that the WRG running does not generate anychiral-symmetry-violating (CSV) interaction, provided that we start with anoperator which does not contain a CSV term. We analytically show how thecounter terms are generated in the WRG running in case of the infinitesimalcutoff reduction. Based on the analytic result, we argue a range of the cutoffvariation for which the running of the counter terms is of natural size.

direct_prompt: We compare the observed kinematics to various proposed formation mechanisms for the dust structures. The most consistent scenario is that these filaments were stretched from clumps of gas by shearing from Galactic Center winds or the gravitational potential of orbiting molecular clouds. This has implications for the origin and fate of diffuse interstellar material within the harsh central environment. Going forward, continued monitoring of the filaments' motions will help constrain dynamical models of gas flows and tidal forces in this region. The proper motion measurements also provide a new way to identify embedded young stellar objects and study triggered star formation around Sagittarius A*. Overall, our results characterize for the first time the 3D kinematics of some of the smallest diffuse features near the Galactic Center black hole.
human_text: Then across-correlation technique could be performed in order to determine theoffsets between the features with respect to their position in the referenceepoch. Results: We derive the proper motions of a number of filaments and 2cometary shaped dusty sources close (in projection) to SgrA*. We show that theshape and the motion of the filaments does not agree with a purely Keplerianmotion of the gas in the potential of the supermassive black hole at theposition of SgrA*. Therefore, additional mechanisms must be responsible fortheir formation and motion. We argue that the properties of the filaments areprobably related to an outflow from the disk of young mass-losing stars aroundSgrA*. In part, the outflow may originate from the black hole itself. We alsopresent some evidence and theoretical considerations that the outflow may becollimated.

direct_prompt: Here is a 4 sentence abstract for the provided article title:Magnetoelectric CuFeO$_2$ exhibits a rich magnetic phase diagram driven by competing exchange interactions. We use spin-polarized density functional theory calculations to determine the magnetic exchange parameters in CuFeO$_2$, focusing on the biquadratic antisymmetric exchange interaction. Our results show that the biquadratic antisymmetric exchange plays a significant role in stabilizing the incommensurate phases observed in CuFeO$_2$ at low temperatures. This work elucidates the origin of the unusual magnetic orderings in CuFeO$_2$ and establishes biquadratic antisymmetric exchange as an important energy term that shapes the magnetic phase diagram of this multiferroic material.
human_text: Biquadratic {\it antisymmetric} exchange terms of the form $ - [C_{ij}e^{\alpha}_{ij}({\bf s}_i\times{\bf s}_j)_z]^2$, where ${\bf e}_{ij}$ is theunit vector connecting sites $i$ and $j$ and $\alpha = x,y$, due partially tomagnetoelectric coupling effects, are shown to be responsible for the spin-flophelical phase in CuFeO$_2$ at low magnetic field and temperature. Usualbiquadratic {\it symmetric} exchange, likely due to magnetoelastic coupling, isfound to support the stability of axial magnetic states at higher fields inthis nearly-Heisenberg like stacked triangular antiferromagnet. A modelHamiltonian which also includes substantial interplane and higher-neighborintraplane exchange interactions, reproduces the unique series of observedcommensurate and incommensurate periodicity phases with increasing appliedmagnetic field in this highly frustrated system. The magnetic field-temperaturephase diagram is discussed in terms of a Landau-type free energy.

direct_prompt: Here is a 7 sentence abstract for the provided article title:The behaviors of polydisperse particle systems during phase transitions have been difficult to characterize but provide useful insights. This study examines the disordering transition and peak effect phenomenon in systems of varied particle sizes using computer simulations. Systems with a wide range of particle sizes were modeled to undergo melting or solidification over a range of temperatures. The results show an irregular disordering process with spatial heterogeneities that persist longer for wider particle size distributions. An increased probability of defects such as dislocation pairs was also found near melting temperatures for polydisperse systems. Most notably, an amplified peak effect in the dynamic properties prior to transition was observed for systems with a broader size distribution.
human_text: In the presence of quenched disorder thisdisordering transition coincides with a marked increase in the depinningthreshold, known as a peak effect. We find that the addition of poorly pinnedparticles can increase the overall pinning in the sample by increasing theamount of topological disorder present. If the quenched disorder is strongenough to create a significant amount of topological disorder in themonodisperse system, addition of a poorly pinned species generates furtherdisorder but does not produce a peak in the depinning force. Our resultsindicate that for binary mixtures, optimal pinning occurs for topologicaldefect fraction densities of 0.2 to 0.25. For defect densities below thisrange, the system retains orientational order. We determine the effect of thepinning density, strength, and radius on the depinning peak and find that thepeak effect is more pronounced in weakly pinning systems.

direct_prompt: Here is a 5 sentence abstract for the article title:The discovery of optimal pathways to induce ordering in spin systems has applications in materials science and quantum information processing. This article presents a method for finding geodesics - shortest paths - between ordered and disordered states in finite Ising spin chains. By minimizing the number of single spin-flips required, geodesics allow for efficient creation and propagation of order. The authors develop an algorithm to compute geodesics exactly for spin chains of any length. Simulation results demonstrate that geodesics can induce order using up to 50% fewer spin-flips than naïve ordering methods. This geodesic approach could provide new techniques for transforming between states in spin systems for quantum technologies.
human_text: Experiments in coherent nuclear and electron magnetic resonance, and opticalspectroscopy correspond to control of quantum mechanical ensembles, guidingthem from initial to final target states by unitary transformations. Thecontrol inputs (pulse sequences) that accomplish these unitary transformationsshould take as little time as possible so as to minimize the effects ofrelaxation and decoherence and to optimize the sensitivity of the experiments.Here we give efficient syntheses of various unitary transformations on Isingspin chains of arbitrary length. The efficient realization of the unitarytransformations presented here is obtained by computing geodesics on a sphereunder a special metric. We show that contrary to the conventional belief, it ispossible to propagate a spin order along an Ising spin chain with couplingstrength J (in units of Hz), significantly faster than 1/(2J) per step.

direct_prompt: Here is a 6 sentence abstract for the given article title:We investigate properties of a recursive boson system described by operators acting on the Cuntz algebra ${\cal O}_{\infty}$. The Cuntz algebra provides an ideal framework to represent infinite modes of a quantum harmonic oscillator. We define creation and annihilation operators for each oscillator mode that satisfy the Cuntz relations of the algebra. We examine the action of these operators on Fock space and study properties of the corresponding number operator. The recursive structure of the boson system leads to self-similar behaviour under scale transformations. Our results provide insight into the role of scale invariance and scaling properties for infinite bosonic systems described by the Cuntz algebra.
human_text: Bosons and fermions are often written by elements of other algebras. M. Abegave a recursive realization of the boson by formal infinite sums of thecanonical generators of the Cuntz algebra ${\cal O}_{\infty}$. We show thatsuch formal infinite sum always makes sense on a certain dense subspace of anypermutative representation of ${\cal O}_{\infty}$. In this meaning, we canregard as if the algebra ${\cal B}$ of bosons was a unital $*$-subalgebra of${\cal O}_{\infty}$ on a given permutative representation by keeping theirunboundedness. By this relation, we compute branching laws arising fromrestrictions of representations of ${\cal O}_{\infty}$ on ${\cal B}$. Forexample, it is shown that the Fock representation of ${\cal B}$ is given as therestriction of the standard representation of ${\cal O}_{\infty}$ on ${\calB}$.

direct_prompt: However, in most models, gauge mediation suffers from the little hierarchy problem: the messenger fields which mediate the interactions between the supersymmetry breaking sector and the observable sector tend to acquire large masses due to supersymmetry breaking effects. This can lead to unnaturally large contributions to the Higgs mass. In this paper, we propose a solution to the little hierarchy problem in gauge mediation using emergent supersymmetry. Emergent supersymmetry is a new mechanism for supersymmetry breaking which relies on the dynamics of strongly coupled gauge theories. In our model, the messenger fields are charged under a hidden gauge group which is strongly coupled at the messenger mass scale. The strong dynamics of the hidden gauge group generate a large anomalous dimension for the messenger fields, which suppresses their masses.
human_text: We investigated the viability of neutralino dark matter in the gaugemediation from emergent supersymmetry proposal. In this proposal, supersymmetryis broken at Planck scale and consequently, the gravitino is superheavy andcompletely decouples from the low energy theory. Squarks and sleptons obtaintheir soft masses dominantly through gauge mediation with other mechanismshighly suppressed. The lightest supersymmetric partner, in contrast totraditional gauge mediation, is a neutralino which is also a dark mattercandidate. By explicit calculation of the low energy spectra, the parameterspace was constrained using the WMAP observed relic density of dark matter,LEP2 Higgs mass bounds, collider bounds on supersymmetric partners and exoticB-meson decays. We found that the model has intriguing hybrid features such asa nearly gauge-mediated spectrum (the exception being the superheavy gravitino)but with a dominant mSUGRA-like bino-stau coannihilation channel and at large$\tan \beta$, A-resonance-like annihilation.

direct_prompt: Tight binding formulation of the dielectric response in semiconductor nanocrystalsWe present a tight-binding formulation of the dielectric response in semiconductor nanocrystals. The formulation is based on a generalized dielectric constant that takes into account the effects of both the crystal structure and the quantum confinement. We show that the generalized dielectric constant can be used to calculate the optical absorption spectrum of semiconductor nanocrystals. We also show that the generalized dielectric constant can be used to calculate the dielectric constant of semiconductor nanocrystals in an external electric field. Our formulation provides a unified description of the dielectric response of semiconductor nanocrystals that is valid for both the weak and strong confinement regimes. It can be used to calculate the optical properties of semiconductor nanocrystals, as well as their dielectric properties in an external electric field.
human_text: Extending to thenanoscale the Hanke and Sham approach [Phys. Rev. B 12, 4501 (1975)] developedfor bulk semiconductors, we show how local field effects can be included in thestudy of confined systems. A great advantage of this scheme is that of beingformulated in terms of localized orbitals and thus it requires very fewcomputational resources and times. Applications to the optical and screeningproperties of semiconductor nanocrystals are presented here and discussed.Results concerning the absorption cross section, the static polarizability andthe screening function of InAs (direct gap) and Si (indirect gap) nanocrystalscompare well to both first principles results and experimental data. We alsoshow that the present scheme allows us to easily go beyond the continuumdielectric model, based on the Clausius-Mossotti equation, which is frequentlyused to include the nanocrystal surface polarization.

direct_prompt: Abstract:We present the development of a new, three-dimensional, Lagrangian magnetohydrodynamics (MHD) code called MAGMA (MHD Applications using a Godunov Method and Adaptive mesh refinement). The primary goal of this project is to model the merger of magnetized neutron stars following their formation in the core collapse of massive stars. Our Godunov-type MHD solver is designed to handle strong shocks, large density and pressure contrasts, and magnetic fields. The integration of the ordinary differential equations is performed using a third-order Runge-Kutta scheme. The code uses a cell-centered finite-volume scheme to solve the MHD equations. The spatial reconstruction of the variables is based on the piecewise parabolic method (PPM). Adaptive mesh refinement (AMR) is used to locally increase the resolution where needed, reducing the computational cost.
human_text: We present a new, completely Lagrangian magnetohydrodynamics code that isbased on the SPH method. The equations of self-gravitating hydrodynamics arederived self-consistently from a Lagrangian and account for variable smoothinglength (``grad-h''-) terms in both the hydrodynamic and the gravitationalacceleration equations. The evolution of the magnetic field is formulated interms of so-called Euler potentials which are advected with the fluid and thusguarantee the MHD flux-freezing condition. This formulation is equivalent to avector potential approach and therefore fulfills the$\vec{\nabla}\cdot\vec{B}=0$-constraint by construction. Extensive tests inone, two and three dimensions are presented. The tests demonstrate theexcellent conservation properties of the code and show the clear superiority ofthe Euler potentials over earlier magnetic SPH formulations.

The results of this study provide a better understanding of the conformational properties of bottle-brush polymers and their potential applications.

direct_prompt: Matroid pathwidth is a recently introduced graph parameter that generalizes both treewidth and pathwidth.It has been shown to be fixed-parameter tractable for many classic optimization problems.In this paper, we study the relationship between matroid pathwidth and the complexity of trellis decoding in linear codes.We show that every linear code over a finite field of constant size has a trellis with matroid pathwidth at most two.This implies that the maximum likelihood decoding problem for such codes can be solved in time \(O(n^3)\), where \(n\) is the block length of the code.We also show that there exist linear codes whose trellis has matroid pathwidth at least 3.This implies that the maximum likelihood decoding problem for such codes cannot be solved in time \(O(n^3)\) unless the exponential time hypothesis fails.
human_text: We relate the notion of matroid pathwidth to the minimum trellisstate-complexity (which we term trellis-width) of a linear code, and to thepathwidth of a graph. By reducing from the problem of computing the pathwidthof a graph, we show that the problem of determining the pathwidth of arepresentable matroid is NP-hard. Consequently, the problem of computing thetrellis-width of a linear code is also NP-hard. For a finite field $\F$, wealso consider the class of $\F$-representable matroids of pathwidth at most$w$, and correspondingly, the family of linear codes over $\F$ withtrellis-width at most $w$. These are easily seen to be minor-closed. Sincethese matroids (and codes) have branchwidth at most $w$, a result of Geelen andWhittle shows that such matroids (and the corresponding codes) arecharacterized by finitely many excluded minors.

direct_prompt: The system is designed to remove impurities from hydrogen gas to a level of less than 1 ppb. The system consists of a palladium diffuser, a liquid nitrogen cold trap, and a gas purifier. The palladium diffuser removes hydrogen isotopes other than protium, and the liquid nitrogen cold trap removes condensible impurities. The gas purifier removes non-condensible impurities, such as oxygen, nitrogen, and carbon monoxide. The system has been tested and shown to be capable of purifying hydrogen gas to a level of less than 1 ppb.The system is fully automated and can be operated continuously for long periods of time. The system is also relatively compact and lightweight, making it ideal for use in a variety of applications.The system has been used to purify hydrogen gas for the MuCap experiment.

direct_prompt: Here is a potential abstract for your academic article:This study investigates the transport properties of microstructured ultrathin films of La0.67Ca0.33MnO3 (LCMO) on SrTiO3 (STO) substrates. The transport properties of the films were measured using a four-probe technique. The results showed that the films exhibited a metal-insulator transition at a temperature of around 250 K. The resistivity of the films was found to decrease with increasing film thickness. The Hall coefficient of the films was found to be positive, indicating that the films are n-type semiconductors. The magnetoresistance of the films was found to be negative, indicating that the films exhibit ferromagnetic behavior.
human_text: We have investigated the electrical transport properties of 8 nm thickLa0.67Ca0.33MnO3 films, sputter-deposited on SrTiO3 (STO), and etched into 5micrometer-wide bridges by Ar-ion etching. We find that even slight overetchingof the film leads to conductance of the STO substrate, and asymmetric andnon-linear current-voltage (I-V) characteristics. However, a brief oxygenplasma etch allows full recovery of the insulating character of the substrate.The I-V characteristics of the bridges are then fully linear over a large rangeof current densities. We find colossal magnetoresistance properties typical forstrained LCMO on STO but no signature of non-linear effects (so-calledelectroresistance) connected to electronic inhomogeneites. direct_prompt: X-ray emissions from two-temperature accretion flows within a dipole magnetic funnelAbstract:Accretion flows onto neutron stars are often associated with strong magnetic fields, and the accretion columns are likely to be channeled by the magnetic fields to form a funnel-like structure. In this work, we study the X-ray emissions from such accretion flows in the dipole magnetic field, considering the thermal and non-thermal processes simultaneously. We find that the thermal bremsstrahlung emission from the accreting matter and the synchrotron emission from the secondary pairs dominate the spectra. The radiation pressure plays an important role in the accretion dynamics. Our calculations show that, under some conditions, the radiation force can significantly reduce the accretion luminosity and even blow away the accretion flow, leading to an effective suppression of the radiation.
human_text: We investigate the hydrodynamics of accretion channelled by a dipolarmagnetic field (funnel flows). We consider situations in which the electronsand ions in the flow cannot maintain thermal equilibrium (two-temperatureeffects) due to strong radiative loss, and determine the effects on the keVX-ray properties of the systems. We apply this model to investigate theaccretion shocks of white dwarfs in magnetic cataclysmic variables. We havefound that the incorporation of two-temperature effects could harden the keVX-rays. Also, the dipolar model yields harder X-ray spectra than the standardplanar model if white dwarf is sufficiently massive (>~1M_sun). When fittingobserved keV X-ray spectra of magnetic cataclysmic variables, the inclusion oftwo-temperature hydrodynamics and a dipolar accretion geometry lowers estimatesfor white-dwarf masses when compared with masses inferred from models excludingthese effects. We find mass reductions <~9% in the most massive cases.

direct_prompt: The CO intensity-weighted mean velocity and velocity dispersion are measured for each galaxy. We investigate the differences in the global CO properties between barred and non-barred galaxies. The barred galaxies tend to have lower CO velocity dispersions compared with the non-barred galaxies. We find that barred galaxies show a variety of distributions of molecular gas. About 20% of the barred galaxies show the concentration of molecular gas toward the center, while the others do not show such concentration. About 40% of the barred galaxies show the enhancement of molecular gas in the bar region. We also examine the spatial distribution of the peak CO intensity in each galaxy. Most of the galaxies show a peak in the central region, however, about 20% of the galaxies show an off-center peak.

direct_prompt: Goldstone models are effective field theories describing the low energy dynamics of spontaneously broken global symmetries. In this work, we consider Goldstone models in D+1 dimensions, where D=3,4,5, and study the conditions for the existence of stable and zero topological charge solitons. We find that in D=3 and D=4, stable and zero topological charge solitons exist for a wide range of parameters. In D=5, we find that stable solitons exist, but they are only zero topological charge for a specific choice of parameters. Our results provide new insights into the dynamics of Goldstone models and the properties of solitons in higher dimensions.

Both topologically stable multisolitons with arbitrary windingnumbers, and zero topological charge soliton--antisoliton solutions areconstructed numerically in D=3,4,5. We have explored the types of symmetriesthe systems should be subjected to, for there to exist multisoliton andsoliton--antisoliton pairs in D=3,4,5,6. These findings are underpinned byconstructing numerical solutions in the $D\le 5$ examples. Subject to axialsymmetry, only multisolitons of all topological charges exist in even D, and inodd D, only zero and unit topological charge solutions exist. Subjecting thesystem to weaker than axial symmetries, results in the existence of all thepossibilities in all dimensions. Our findings apply also to finite 'energy'solutions to Yang--Mills and Yang-Mills--Higgs systems, and in principle alsosigma models.

direct_prompt: In this paper, we present a study of the internetwork emission in the 1.3 mm continuum with ALMA at 0.″3 resolution. Using these data, together with additional data from the SMA and the Nobeyama Radioheliograph (NoRH) at 1.3, 2.0, 3.5, 9.0, and 17.0 mm, we investigate the physical properties of the internetwork. We find that the brightness temperature of the quiet Sun at 1.3 mm is 13,000 ± 1000 K. We find that the emission at 1.3 mm is dominated by thermal dust emission and that the contribution from free–free emission and gyrosynchrotron emission is small. Our results suggest that magnetic fields in the internetwork are weak (∼10–50 G). We compare our results with previous studies of the quiet Sun at millimeter wavelengths and discuss the implications for coronal heating.

direct_prompt: **Abstract:**This paper presents a new protocol for the secure sharing of random bits over the Internet. The protocol is based on the idea of using a shared secret key to encrypt the random bits. The key is generated using a novel key generation algorithm that is based on the hardness of the factoring problem. The protocol is secure against eavesdropping and man-in-the-middle attacks. It is also efficient and can be implemented using a variety of different cryptographic libraries. We have implemented the protocol and tested it on a variety of different networks. The results show that the protocol is both secure and efficient.
human_text: Although one-time pad encrypted files can be sent through Internet channels,the need for renewing shared secret keys have made this method unpractical.This work presents a scheme to turn practical the fast sharing of random keysover arbitrary Internet channels. Starting with a shared secret key sequence oflength K_0 the users end up with a secure new sequence K >> K_0. Using thesesequences for posteriori message encryption the legitimate users have absolutesecurity control without the need for third parties. Additionally, the securitylevel does not depend on the unproven difficulty of factoring numbers inprimes. In the proposed scheme a fast optical random source generates randombits and noise for key renewals. The transmitted signals are recorded signalsthat carries both the random binary signals to be exchanged and physical noisethat cannot be eliminated by the attacker.

direct_prompt: **Abstract**This paper presents a spectroscopic study of the old open cluster NGC 1883, based on high-resolution spectra obtained at the 2.2-m telescope of the German-Spanish Astronomical Center (CAHA), Calar Alto Observatory, Spain. We measured radial velocities for 53 cluster member candidates and derived a mean radial velocity of −47.4 ± 0.6 km s−1 and a velocity dispersion of 2.2 ± 0.4 km s−1. The metallicity of the cluster was estimated using the [Fe/H] abundance ratio, yielding a value of −0.26 ± 0.06 dex. We also determined the cluster's reddening, E(B − V) = 0.09 ± 0.02 mag, and distance, 1.82 ± 0.09 kpc. The derived age and metallicity are consistent with NGC 1883 being an old, metal-poor open cluster.
human_text: The aim is to derive the cluster membership,velocity and metallicity, and discuss recent claims in the literature (Tadross2005) that NGC 1883 is as metal poor as globular clusters in the Halo. Besides,being one of the few outer Galactic disk intermediate-age open clusters knownso far, it is an ideal target to improve our knowledge of the Galactic diskradial abundance gradient, that is a basic ingredient for any chemicalevolution model of the Milky Way. The new data we obtained allow us to put NGC1883's basic parameters more reliable. We find that the cluster has a meanmetallicity of [Fe/H] = -0.20$\pm$0.22, from which we infer an age(650$^{+70}_{-70}$ Myr) close to the Hyades one and a Galactocentric distanceof 12.3$^{+0.4}_{-0.2}$ kpc. The metal abundance, kinematics, and position makeNGC 1883 a genuine outer disk intermediate-age open cluster.

direct_prompt: Abstract—The increasing demand for highly reliable industrial machinery and processes has promoted the development of powerful and cost-effective condition monitoring systems for continuous and preventive maintenance. This paper reviews the fundamentals, techniques and applications of computational intelligence in condition monitoring, with the focus on the recent significant advances. Firstly, the paper introduces the general concept of condition monitoring and explores the role of computational intelligence techniques in addressing condition monitoring challenges. Secondly, a comprehensive review of various soft computing and machine learning techniques employed for condition monitoring is presented. Subsequently, some representative applications of computational intelligence in condition monitoring, such as fault diagnosis and prognosis, are elaborated and discussed. The paper highlights the strengths, limitations, and future directions of the computational intelligence techniques for condition monitoring.
human_text: This paper presents bushing condition monitoring frameworks that usemulti-layer perceptrons (MLP), radial basis functions (RBF) and support vectormachines (SVM) classifiers. The first level of the framework determines if thebushing is faulty or not while the second level determines the type of fault.The diagnostic gases in the bushings are analyzed using the dissolve gasanalysis. MLP gives superior performance in terms of accuracy and training timethan SVM and RBF. In addition, an on-line bushing condition monitoringapproach, which is able to adapt to newly acquired data are introduced. Thisapproach is able to accommodate new classes that are introduced by incomingdata and is implemented using an incremental learning algorithm that uses MLP.The testing results improved from 67.5% to 95.8% as new data were introducedand the testing results improved from 60% to 95.3% as new conditions wereintroduced.

direct_prompt: Boundary Harnack inequalities for regional fractional LaplacianIn this paper, we establish boundary Harnack inequalities for solutions to elliptic equations involving the regional fractional Laplacian. Our results extend the classical boundary Harnack inequalities for the Laplacian and the fractional Laplacian to the regional fractional Laplacian setting. Our approach is based on the construction of appropriate barrier functions and the use of the maximum principle. Our results have applications to the study of boundary behavior of solutions to elliptic equations involving the regional fractional Laplacian.
human_text: We consider boundary Harnack inequalities for regional fractional Laplacianwhich are generators of censored stable-like processes on G taking\kappa(x,y)/|x-y|^{n+\alpha}dxdy, x,y\in G as the jumping measure. When G is aC^{1,\beta-1} open set, 1<\alpha<\beta\leq 2 and \kappa\inC^{1}(\overline{G}\times \overline{G}) bounded between two positive numbers, weprove a boundary Harnack inequality giving dist(x,\partial G)^{\alpha-1} orderdecay for harmonic functions near the boundary. For a C^{1,\beta-1} open setD\subset \overline{D}\subset G, 0<\alpha\leq (1\vee\alpha)<\beta\leq 2, weprove a boundary Harnack inequality giving dist(x,\partial D)^{\alpha/2} orderdecay for harmonic functions near the boundary. These inequalities aregeneralizations of the known results for the homogeneous case on C^{1,1} opensets. We also prove the boundary Harnack inequality for regional fractionalLaplacian on Lipschitz domain.

direct_prompt: The films were deposited at different pO2 ranging from 10−6 to 10−2 Torr, and their properties were characterized using X-ray diffraction, atomic force microscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, superconducting quantum interference device magnetometry, and Hall effect measurements. The results showed that the films exhibited a single-phase rutile structure with a (110) preferred orientation. The lattice parameters and the grain size of the films increased with increasing pO2. The films were found to be ferromagnetic at room temperature, and the magnetic moment increased with increasing pO2. The electrical resistivity of the films decreased with increasing pO2, and the films exhibited a semiconducting behavior. The results of this study suggest that the oxygen partial pressure plays an important role in determining the structural, transport, and magnetic properties of Co-doped TiO2 films.
human_text: Thin films of Co-TiO2 are deposited on silicon and quartz substrates usingPulse Laser Deposition (PLD) process at various oxygen partial pressuresranging from 6.6 x 10-3 Pascals (Pa) to 53 Pa. Crystal structure, transport andmagnetic properties of reduced CoxTi(1-x)O2 (0 <x< 0.03) thin films areinvestigated and are found to have a strong dependence on the oxygen partialpressure. X-ray diffraction (XRD) data reveals the presence of mixed phasematerial containing both anatase and rutile. However, these phasesintertransform with the change in the oxygen partial pressure in the chamberduring the growth of the films. X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) shows noCo or CoO related peaks for samples with Co concentration up to x=0.03.However, the oxygen 1s peaks are asymmetric suggesting the presence of oxygenvacancies. The transport and magnetic measurements show a clear dependence onthe concentration of oxygen vacancies.

direct_prompt: Observation of Landau levels of Dirac fermions in graphiteThe electronic properties of graphite have been a topic of great interest since the discovery of graphene, a single layer of graphite. In this paper, we report the observation of Landau levels of Dirac fermions in graphite, which are a consequence of the unique electronic structure of graphene. We measured the electrical conductivity of graphite as a function of magnetic field and temperature, and observed a series of Shubnikov–de Haas oscillations. direct_prompt: Effects of Electron-Lattice Coupling on Charge Order in $\theta$-(ET)$_2$XUnconventional superconductivity often emerges from strong electronic correlations. In particular, charge order, in which the charge distribution exhibits a regular pattern, is often considered as a precursor to superconductivity. The interplay between charge order and lattice distortion, known as electron-lattice coupling, is crucial to understanding the mechanism of unconventional superconductivity. In this paper, we investigate the effects of electron-lattice coupling on charge order in $\theta$-(ET)$_2$X, a quasi-two-dimensional organic conductor. We use a combination of theoretical calculations and experimental measurements to show that the electron-lattice coupling leads to a significant enhancement of the charge order and a decrease in the superconducting transition temperature. Our results provide new insights into the role of electron-lattice coupling in unconventional superconductors.
human_text: Charge ordering accompanied by lattice distortion in quasi-two dimensionalorganic conductors \theta-(ET)2X (ET=BEDT-TTF) is studied by using an extendedHubbard model with Peierls-type electron-lattice couplings within theHartree-Fock approximation. It is found that the horizontal-stripecharge-ordered state, which is experimentally observed in\theta-(ET)2RbZn(SCN)4, is stabilized by the self-consistently determinedlattice distortion. Furthermore, in the presence of the anisotropy innearest-neighbor Coulomb interactions Vij, the horizontal charge order becomesmore stable than any other charge patterns such as diagonal, vertical and3-fold-type states. At finite temperatures, we compare the free energies ofvarious charge-ordered states and find a first-order transition from a metallicstate with 3-fold charge order to the insulating state with the horizontalcharge order. The role of lattice degrees of freedom in the realization of thehorizontal charge order and the relevance to experiments on \theta-(ET)2X arediscussed.

We find that the scalar perturbations are localized on the brane and that their amplitude is suppressed compared to the amplitude of the scalar perturbations in the bulk. We also find that the scalar perturbations can be used to probe the properties of the braneworld model.
human_text: We study the behaviour of scalar perturbations in the radiation-dominated eraof Randall-Sundrum braneworld cosmology by numerically solving the coupled bulkand brane master wave equations. We find that density perturbations withwavelengths less than a critical value (set by the bulk curvature length) areamplified during horizon re-entry. This means that the radiation era matterpower spectrum will be at least an order of magnitude larger than thepredictions of general relativity (GR) on small scales. Conversely, weexplicitly confirm from simulations that the spectrum is identical to GR onlarge scales. Although this magnification is not relevant for the cosmicmicrowave background or measurements of large scale structure, it will havesome bearing on the formation of primordial black holes in Randall-Sundrummodels.

direct_prompt: Applications of tripled chaotic maps in cryptographyChaotic maps have been widely used in cryptography due to their ergodic, unpredictable, and sensitive to initial conditions properties. In this paper, we propose a novel cryptographic scheme based on tripled chaotic maps. The proposed scheme is composed of three layers of chaotic maps, which makes it more secure and robust against cryptanalysis. We analyze the security of the proposed scheme and demonstrate its effectiveness through simulations. Experimental results show that the proposed scheme can effectively resist various attacks, including statistical attacks, differential attacks, and brute-force attacks. The proposed scheme is suitable for secure communication in various applications, such as the Internet of Things, cloud computing, and wireless sensor networks.

Newalgorithms based on chaotic maps were suggested for protection of differenttypes of multimedia data, especially digital images and videos in this period.However, many of them fundamentally were flawed by a lack of robustness andsecurity. For getting higher security and higher complexity, in the currentpaper, we introduce a new kind of symmetric key block cipher algorithm that isbased on \emph{tripled chaotic maps}. In this algorithm, the utilization of twocoupling parameters, as well as the increased complexity of the cryptosystem,make a contribution to the development of cryptosystem with higher security. Inorder to increase the security of the proposed algorithm, the size of key spaceand the computational complexity of the coupling parameters should be increasedas well.

This strict inequality has applications to conformal spingeometry. -----  Soit $(M,g,\si)$ une vari\'et\'e spinorielle compacte de dimension $n \geq2$. %Si $\tilde{g} \in [g]$ est une m\'etrique conforme \`a $g$, On note$\lambda_1^+(\tilde{g})$ la plus petite valeur propre $>0$ de l'op\'erateur deDirac dans la m\'etrique $\tilde{g} \in [g]$ conforme \`a $g$. On d\'efinit$\lamin(M,[g],\si) = \inf_{\tilde{g} \in [g]} \lambda_1^+(\tilde{g})  \Vol(M,\tilde{g})^{1/n} $. On montre que $0< \lamin(M,[g],\si) \leq\lamin(\mS^n)$. %= \frac{n}{2} \om_n^{{1 \over n}}$ On trouve des conditionssuffisantes pour lesquelles on obtient l'in\'egalit\'e stricte$\lamin(M,[g],\si) < \lamin(\mS^n)$.

direct_prompt: [Abstract]: In this paper, we study the asymptotic properties of duration-driven long-range dependent (LDR) processes. We consider a general class of LDR processes, including fractional Brownian motion and fractional Gaussian noise, and derive their asymptotic distributions under various conditions. Our results provide a comprehensive understanding of the limiting behavior of duration-driven LDR processes, which can be useful in a variety of applications, such as telecommunications, queuing theory, and finance.Specifically, we first establish the weak convergence of duration-driven LDR processes to a Gaussian process. We then derive the exact form of the limiting Gaussian process and characterize its properties. Furthermore, we investigate the asymptotic behavior of the sample mean and sample variance of duration-driven LDR processes and obtain their limiting distributions. Our results are derived using a combination of techniques from probability theory and functional analysis.
human_text: We consider processes with second order long range dependence resulting fromheavy tailed durations. We refer to this phenomenon as duration-driven longrange dependence (DDLRD), as opposed to the more widely studied linear longrange dependence based on fractional differencing of an $iid$ process. Weconsider in detail two specific processes having DDLRD, originally presented inTaqqu and Levy (1986), and Parke (1999). For these processes, we obtain thelimiting distribution of suitably standardized discrete Fourier transforms(DFTs) and sample autocovariances. At low frequencies, the standardized DFTsconverge to a stable law, as do the standardized sample autocovariances atfixed lags. Finite collections of standardized sample autocovariances at afixed set of lags converge to a degenerate distribution. The standardized DFTsat high frequencies converge to a Gaussian law. Our asymptotic results arestrikingly similar for the two DDLRD processes studied.

direct_prompt: Nonlinear generalized functions and the Heisenberg-Pauli foundations of Quantum Field TheoryIn this paper, we introduce a new approach to the foundations of quantum field theory based on nonlinear generalized functions. This approach allows us to resolve the ultraviolet divergences that plague traditional approaches to quantum field theory and to provide a rigorous foundation for the Heisenberg-Pauli interpretation of quantum mechanics.We begin by introducing the concept of a nonlinear generalized function and discuss its properties. We then show how nonlinear generalized functions can be used to construct a new formulation of quantum field theory that is free of ultraviolet divergences. Finally, we discuss the implications of our new approach for the Heisenberg-Pauli interpretation of quantum mechanics.Our new approach to the foundations of quantum field theory provides a number of advantages over traditional approaches.
human_text: (i) Domains of the interacting field operators: a priori the H-Pcalculations give time dependent dense domains, what is not very convenient;(ii) Calculations of the resulting matrix elements of the S operator: from theunitarity of the S operator as a whole there are no longer ``infinities,'' buta priori there is no other hope than heavy computer calculations; (iii)Connection with renormalization theory: it should provide an approximation whenthe coupling constant is small. The aim of this paper is to present, on thegrounds of a standard mathematical model of QFT (a self interacting scalarboson field), a basis for improvement without significant prerequisites inmathematics and physics. It is an attempt to use nonlinear generalizedfunctions in QFT, starting directly from the calculations made by physicists,in the same way as they have already been used in classical mechanics andgeneral relativity.

Our results show that our algorithm can significantly improve the degree of crystallization in a network.

Inthe course of this analysis, we develop a new technique for characterizing thelarge-deviations behavior of certain sums of dependent random variables. direct_prompt: Towards a library of synthetic galaxy spectra and preliminary results of  classification and parametrization of unresolved galaxies for GaiaWe present a method to generate a library of synthetic galaxy spectra covering a wide range of physical parameters. The library is based on stellar population synthesis models and takes into account the effects of dust extinction and nebular emission. We use the library to classify and parametrize a sample of unresolved galaxies observed by the Gaia satellite. We find that the majority of the galaxies in our sample are star-forming galaxies with a relatively young stellar population. We also find a small number of galaxies that are either passive or have a very old stellar population. Our results demonstrate the potential of using synthetic galaxy spectra to study the properties of unresolved galaxies.
human_text: Aims:The Gaia astrometric survey mission will, as a consequence of itsscanning law, obtain low resolution optical (330-1000 nm) spectrophotometry ofseveral million unresolved galaxies brighter than V=22. We present the firststeps in a project to design and implement a classification system for thesedata. The goal is both to determine morphological classes and to estimateintrinsic astrophysical parameters via synthetic templates. Here we describe(1) a new library of synthetic galaxy spectra, and (2) first results ofclassification and parametrization experiments using simulated Gaiaspectrophotometry of this library. Methods:We have created a large grid ofsynthetic galaxy spectra using the PEGASE.2 code, which is based on galaxyevolution models that take into account metallicity evolution, extinctioncorrection, emission lines (with stellar spectra based on the BaSeL library).Our classification and regression models are Support Vector Machines (SVMs),which are kernel-based nonlinear estimators.

direct_prompt: Our waveforms, dubbed SEOBNRv4HM, are constructed by directly evolving the equations of motion. These waveforms provide a more accurate description of the dynamics of small-mass-ratio systems than previous Effective-One-Body waveforms, particularly for quasicircular binaries. We validate SEOBNRv4HM waveforms by comparing them with numerical relativity simulations and show that they provide excellent agreement. We also study the convergence of our waveforms with respect to the number of harmonics used in their construction and find that a minimum of four harmonics is required to obtain accurate results.We publicly release our SEOBNRv4HM waveforms through the Black Hole Initial Data Bank. These waveforms can be used to study a variety of astrophysical phenomena involving small-mass-ratio black-hole binaries, such as the merger of stellar-mass black holes and the capture of compact objects by supermassive black holes.

human_text: The numerical modelling of the circumstellar emission where intricateinterplays between physical and chemical processes take place, is a challenge.The derived mass-loss rates depend crucially on the assumptions in thecircumstellar model, of which some can be constrained if enough observationaldata exist. Therefore, a reliable mass-loss-rate determination for anindividual star requires, in addition to a detailed radiative transferanalysis, good observational constraints in the form of multi-line observationsand radial brightness distributions. direct_prompt: [assistant]: Abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to generate Crab giant pulses (GPs) in the framework of the outer gap model. The model is based on the assumption that GPs are produced by a two-step process: (1) a small-scale primary instability develops in the pulsar magnetosphere, leading to the formation of a pair-starved gap; (2) the primary instability triggers a large-scale secondary instability, which results in the generation of a GP. The model is applied to the Crab pulsar, and the results are compared with the observed properties of Crab GPs. We find that the model can successfully reproduce the main features of Crab GPs, including their luminosity, duration, and spectral properties. The model also provides a new insight into the physical mechanism responsible for the generation of Crab GPs.
human_text: We propose that Crab giant pulses are generated on closed magnetic fieldlines near the light cylinder via anomalous cyclotron resonance on the ordinarymode. Waves are generated in a set of fine, unequally spaced, narrow emissionbands at frequencies much lower than a local cyclotron frequency. Location ofemission bands is fitted to spectral structures seen by Eilek et al. (2006). To reproduce the data, the required density of plasma in the giant pulsesemission region is much higher, by a factor $\sim 3 \times 10^5$, than theminimal Goldreich-Julian density. Emission is generated by a population ofhighly energetic particles with radiation-limited Lorentz factors $\gamma \sim7 \times 10^7$, produced during occasional reconnection close to the Y point,where the last closed field lines approach the light cylinder.

We arguethat a standard disk dominates the radiative output for radii larger than acharacteristic transition radius R_c ~ mdot x R_{ISCO}, where mdot is theaccretion rate in Eddington units and R_{ISCO} is the innermost stable orbit.For R_{ISCO} < R < R_c, most of the accretion power is released via non-thermalprocesses. direct_prompt: Direct calculation of interfacial tensions from computer simulation: Results for freely jointed tangent hard sphere chainsThe interfacial tension between coexisting liquid and vapor phases is a fundamental property of fluids, and plays a key role in the behaviour of many chemical and biological systems. However, measuring interfacial tensions accurately is difficult. We present a new method to calculate interfacial tensions between coexisting phases from computer simulations. Unlike previous simulation methods, our approach does not require the free energy of the system to be calculated, and is therefore much more efficient. We have implemented our method for a model system of freely jointed tangent hard sphere chains, and show that it provides accurate results for interfacial tensions over a range of temperatures.
human_text: We develop a methodology for the calculation of surface free energies basedon the probability distribution of a wandering interface. Using a simpleextension of the NpT sampling, we allow the interface area to randomly probethe available space and evaluate the surface free energy from histogramanalysis and the corresponding average. The method is suitable for studyingsystems with either continuous or discontinuous potentials, as it does notrequire explicit evaluation of the virial. The proposed algorithm is comparedwith known results for the surface tension of Lennard--Jones and Square Wellfluid, as well as for the interface tension of a bead--spring polymer model andgood agreement is found. We also calculate interfacial tensions of freelyjointed tangent hard sphere chains on athermal walls for a wide range of chainlengths and densities.

direct_prompt: Abstract:We study the early time dynamics of heavy ion collisions within the framework of AdS/CFT correspondence. We use the gauge/gravity duality to map the strongly coupled dynamics of the quark-gluon plasma produced in heavy ion collisions to the classical evolution of a dual gravitational system. We compute the time evolution of the energy density and pressure of the plasma, and we extract the transport coefficients of the plasma, such as the shear viscosity and the bulk viscosity. Our results provide a better understanding of the early stages of heavy ion collisions and of the properties of the quark-gluon plasma.
human_text: We study the matter produced in heavy ion collisions assuming that thismatter is strongly interacting and employing AdS/CFT correspondence toinvestigate its dynamics. At late proper times we show that Bjorkenhydrodynamics solution, obtained recently by Janik and Peschanski usinggauge-gravity duality [hep-th/0512162], can be singled out by simply requiringthat the metric tensor is a real and single-valued function of the coordinateseverywhere in the bulk, without imposing any constraints on the curvatureinvariant. At early proper times we use similar strategy to show that theenergy density approaches a constant as proper time goes to zero. We thereforedemonstrate that the strong coupling dynamics incorporates the isotropizationtransition in heavy ion collisions. By matching our early-time regime with thelate-time one of Janik and Peschanski we estimate the isotropization time atRHIC to be approximately 0.3 fm/c, in good agreement with results ofhydrodynamic simulations.

direct_prompt: Radiative transfer fits of V and K'-band imagesWe present a study of the dust distribution in edge-on galaxies using radiative transfer fits of V and K'-band images. The sample consists of 12 nearby galaxies with a wide range of morphological types. We use a two-dimensional dust distribution model to fit the observed images, and we derive the dust opacity, scale height, and asymmetry. We find that the dust opacity is typically higher in the inner regions of the galaxies, and that the scale height increases with radius. The dust distribution is also found to be asymmetric in most of the galaxies, with the dust lane being shifted towards the north-east. We compare our results with those of previous studies, and we discuss the implications of our findings for the dust properties and evolution in edge-on galaxies.

Faster radiativetransfer models which neglect scattering can produce equivalent fits, withchanges in the derived parameters within the accuracy of full fits includingscattering. In the K'-band, no trace is found of a second, massive, dust diskwhich has been invoked to explain observations of dust emission in thesubmillimeter. I discuss the model degeneracies and the effect of complexstructures on the fitted distributions.

direct_prompt: **Abstract:**This paper presents a class of low-density parity-check (LDPC) erasure distributions with a closed-form threshold expression. We first introduce the concept of the erasure distribution and discuss its importance in the analysis of LDPC codes. We also derive the density evolution equations for the \(\alpha\)-family and show that they can be used to accurately predict the performance of LDPC codes. Finally, we compare the performance of the \(\alpha\)-family to that of other LDPC erasure distributions and show that it can achieve significant gains in performance.

direct_prompt: However, the system-environment interaction in NMR and the resulting decoherence mechanism remain unclear. Here, by performing integrated theoretical analysis and high-field dynamic nuclear polarization NMR spectroscopy, we identify a previously unrecognized mechanism, environmentally induced quantum dynamical phase transition, for understanding the decoherence dynamics in multi-spin systems. We demonstrate that the environmental spins can undergo a quantum phase transition from a symmetry-broken symmetry-protected topological (SPT) phase to a symmetry-restored trivial phase upon increasing the temperature or decreasing the magnetic field. Such a transition leads to a qualitative change in the system-environment interaction. We show that this change is responsible for the observed non-monotonic temperature and field dependences of decoherence rates. The general concept and the phase transition mechanism identified here can be applied to other interacting quantum many-body systems.
human_text: The control of open quantum systems has a fundamental relevance for fieldsranging from quantum information processing to nanotechnology. Typically, thesystem whose coherent dynamics one wants to manipulate, interacts with anenvironment that smoothly degrades its quantum dynamics. Thus, a preciseunderstanding of the inner mechanisms of this process, called "decoherence", iscritical to develop strategies to control the quantum dynamics. In this thesiswe solved the generalized Liouville-von Neumann quantum master equation toobtain the dynamics of many-spin systems interacting with a spin bath. We alsosolve the spin dynamics within the Keldysh formalism. Both methods lead toidentical solutions and together gave us the possibility to obtain numerousphysical predictions that contrast well with Nuclear Magnetic Resonanceexperiments. We applied these tools for molecular characterizations,development of new numerical methodologies and the control of quantum dynamicsin experimental implementations.

direct_prompt: Study of interacting electrons in graphene under the  renormalized-ring-diagram approximationIn this paper, we study the interacting electrons in graphene under the framework of the renormalized-ring-diagram approximation. By introducing a mass term and a static screening potential, we obtain the single-particle Green's function and the self-energy. We find that the self-energy has a logarithmic singularity at low energies, which is consistent with the Mermin-Wagner theorem. Moreover, we calculate the quasiparticle weight, the effective mass, and the Fermi velocity. Our results show that the interaction between electrons renormalizes the Fermi velocity and the effective mass, and it also leads to a decrease in the quasiparticle weight.
human_text: Using the tight-binding model with long-range Coulomb interactions betweenelectrons, we study some of the electronic properties of graphene. The Coulombinteractions are treated with the renormalized-ring-diagram approximation. Byself-consistently solving the integral equations for the Green function, wecalculate the spectral density. The obtained result is in agreement withexperimental observation. In addition, we also compute the density of states,the distribution functions, and the ground-state energy. Within the presentapproximation, we find that the imaginary part of the self-energy fixed at theFermi momentum varies as quadratic in energy close to the chemical potential,regardless the system is doped or not. This result appears to indicate that theelectrons in graphene always behave like a moderately correlated Fermi liquid.

direct_prompt: Antiferromagnetic spin fluctuations in the metallic phase of quasi-two-dimensional organic superconductorsThe two-dimensional organic superconductors exhibit a variety of electronic states and magnetic properties, which are closely related to the dimensionality of the electronic system and the strength of the electronic correlations. In this paper, we report the results of a study of the magnetic properties of the quasi-two-dimensional organic superconductor  by muon spin relaxation (SR). The results show that the magnetic properties of this material can be described by a two-component model: a Curie-Weiss term and a temperature-independent term. The Curie-Weiss term is attributed to the localized spins of the organic molecules, while the temperature-independent term is attributed to the antiferromagnetic spin fluctuations of the itinerant electrons. The magnitude of the antiferromagnetic spin fluctuations decreases with decreasing temperature, and the correlation length increases with decreasing temperature.
human_text: These materials display antiferromagneticcorrelation lengths which increase with decreasing temperature and grow toseveral lattice constants by T_nmr. It is shown that the fact that thedimensionless Korringa ratio is much larger than unity is inconsistent with abroad class of theoretical models (such as dynamical mean-field theory) whichneglects spatial correlations and/or vertex corrections. For materials close tothe Mott insulating phase the nuclear spin relaxation rate, the Knight shiftand the Korringa ratio all decrease significantly with decreasing temperaturebelow T_nmr. This cannot be described by the M-MMP model and the most naturalexplanation is that a pseudogap, similar to that observed in the underdopedcuprate superconductors, opens up in the density of states below T_nmr. Such apseudogap has recently been predicted to occur in the dimerised organic chargetransfer salts materials by the resonating valence bond (RVB) theory.

direct_prompt: Solutions to master equations of quantum Brownian motion in a general environment with external force are investigated. The influences of both the general environment and external force on quantum Brownian motion are discussed. The Stratonovich calculus and the generalized Caldirola-Kanai representation are introduced to deal with the non-Markovian effect and the external force, respectively. Based on the projection operator technique, two kinds of master equations for the reduced density operator of the Brownian particle are derived: one is in the Schrödinger picture and the other is in the Heisenberg picture. The corresponding quantum Langevin equations are presented. The derived results are valid for the cases of both weak and strong system-environment coupling and the harmonic oscillator as well as the free Brownian particle as a Brownian particle.

D 45, 2843 (1992)] withcoefficients obtained from solutions of integro-differential equations canassume closed functional forms for a fairly general class of spectral densitiesof the environment at arbitrary temperature and coupling strength. As anillustration of these new results we solve the corresponding master equationand calculate, among other physical quantities, the uncertainty function whoselate time behavior can be obtained fully. This produces a formula forinvestigating the standard quantum limit which is central to addressing manytheoretical issues in macroscopic quantum phenomena and experimental concernsrelated to low temperature precision measurements. We find that any initialstate always settles down to a Gaussian density matrix whose covariance isdetermined by the thermal reservoir and whose mean is determined by theexternal force.

direct_prompt: Chemical enrichment of galaxy clusters is a complex process involving various physical mechanisms. We use hydrodynamical simulations to study the chemical enrichment of galaxy clusters in a cosmological context. We find that the metallicity of the intracluster medium increases with cluster mass. The radial metallicity profiles show a declining trend, indicating a decrease in the metallicity gradient with increasing cluster mass. Our results suggest that feedback from active galactic nuclei plays an important role in regulating the metal enrichment of galaxy clusters.
human_text: We present cosmological hydrodynamical simulations of galaxy clusters aimedat studying the process of metal enrichment of the intra--cluster medium (ICM).These simulations have been performed by implementing a detailed model ofchemical evolution in the Tree-SPH \gd code. This model allows us to follow themetal release from SNII, SNIa and AGB stars, by properly accounting for thelifetimes of stars of different mass, as well as to change the stellar initialmass function (IMF), the lifetime function and the stellar yields. As such, ourimplementation of chemical evolution represents a powerful instrument to followthe cosmic history of metal production. The simulations presented here havebeen performed with the twofold aim of checking numerical effects, as well asthe impact of changing the model of chemical evolution and the efficiency ofstellar feedback.

direct_prompt: Abstract:In this paper, we perform a comprehensive study of dual computations of non-abelian Yang-Mills theory on the lattice. Our approach combines analytical calculations and numerical simulations. We first derive a new formula for the dual action, which is expressed in terms of the plaquette variables. The non-perturbative running behavior of the coupling in the dual theory is then determined. We also investigate the phase structure of the dual theory using Monte Carlo simulations. The dual theory is found to exhibit a confinement-deconfinement phase transition, which is in line with the expectations from the color confinement mechanism. We compute the critical temperature for this transition and compare it with the results from other approaches. Finally, we discuss the implications of our results for the understanding of non-abelian Yang-Mills theory and its dual formulation.
human_text: In the past several decades there have been a number of proposals forcomputing with dual forms of non-abelian Yang-Mills theories on the lattice.Motivated by the gauge-invariant, geometric picture offered by dual models andsuccessful applications of duality in the U(1) case, we revisit the question ofwhether it is practical to perform numerical computation using non-abelian dualmodels. Specifically, we consider three-dimensional SU(2) pure Yang-Mills as anaccessible yet non-trivial case in which the gauge group is non-abelian. Usingmethods developed recently in the context of spin foam quantum gravity, wederive an algorithm for efficiently computing the dual amplitude and describeMetropolis moves for sampling the dual ensemble. We relate our algorithms toprior work in non-abelian dual computations of Hari Dass and his collaborators,addressing several problems that have been left open.

direct_prompt: In this paper, we propose a novel method to identify WIMP dark matter candidates by measuring both axial and scalar couplings. Our method is based on the fact that WIMPs can interact with nuclei via both spin-dependent and spin-independent interactions. By measuring both types of interactions, we can significantly reduce the background and improve the sensitivity of our search. We present the results of a prototype experiment that we have built to test our method. Our results show that our method is feasible and has the potential to significantly improve the sensitivity of WIMP dark matter searches.
human_text: We study the prospects for detecting Weakly Interacting Massive Particles(WIMPs), in a number of phenomenological scenarios, with a detector composed ofa target simultaneously sensitive to both spin-dependent and spin-independentcouplings, as is the case of COUPP (Chicagoland Observatory for UndergroundParticle Physics). [assistant]: Abstract:Exoplanets orbiting very close to their parent stars, so-called hot Jupiters, are expected to have large day-to-night temperature contrasts and efficient day-to-night heat redistribution. Thermal phase curves, i.e., the variation of the planet's thermal emission as a function of orbital phase, are a powerful tool to probe the day-to-night temperature difference and the day-to-night heat redistribution efficiency. So far, only a handful of hot Jupiters have been observed at thermal wavelengths to construct their thermal phase curves. We present mid-infrared (4.5 \mum) phase curves of the hot Jupiter WASP-121b observed with the Spitzer Space Telescope. The phase curves show significant variations with the amplitude of similar to 20%.

We are able to place2-sigma upper limits of only 2% on the phase variations at these wavelengths.At 8 micron the epoch-to-epoch systematic uncertainty is comparable to thephoton counting noise and we detect a phase function for HD 179949 which is inphase with the planet's orbit and with a relative peak-to-trough amplitude of0.00141(33). Assuming that HD 179949b has a radius R_J < R_p < 1.2R_J, it mustrecirculate less than 21% of incident stellar energy to its night side at the1-sigma level (where 50% signifies full recirculation). If the planet has asmall Bond albedo, it must have a mass less than 2.4 M_J (1-sigma).

direct_prompt: **Abstract**Density functional theory plus Hubbard U (DFT+U) calculations have been performed on heme systems to investigate the electronic structure and spin-state energetics of these important biological cofactors. The DFT+U method is able to accurately reproduce the experimental spin-state ordering of a series of heme complexes, including both high-spin and low-spin states. The calculated electronic structures of the heme complexes are in good agreement with experimental data, and the DFT+U method is shown to be a reliable tool for studying the electronic structure and spin-state energetics of heme systems. The results of this study provide new insights into the electronic structure of heme and its role in biological systems. **Keywords:** Heme; DFT+U; Spin-state energetics; Electronic structure; Biological cofactors
human_text: Besides theircentral role in organometallic chemistry, these compounds represent aparadigmatic case where LDA, GGA, and common hybrid functionals fail toreproduce the experimental magnetic splittings. In particular, the imidazolepentacoordinated heme is incorrectly described as a triplet by all usual DFTflavors. In this study we show that a U parameter close to 4 eV leads to spintransitions and molecular geometries in quantitative agreement withexperiments, and that DFT+U represents an appealing tool in the description ofiron porphyrin complexes, at a much reduced cost compared to correlatedquantum-chemistry methods. The possibility of obtaining the U parameter fromfirst-principles is explored through a self-consistent linear-responseformulation. We find that this approach, which proved to be successful in otheriron systems, produces in this case some overestimation with respect to theoptimal values of U.

We find that, contrary to common perception, theseproperties are not universal but depend on the concentration of chargedimpurities $n_{\rm imp}$. For dirty samples ($250 \times 10^{10} {\rm cm}^{-2}< n_{\rm imp} < 400 \times 10^{10} {\rm cm}^{-2}$), the value of the minimumconductivity at low carrier density is indeed $4 e^2/h$ in agreement with earlyexperiments, with weak dependence on impurity concentration. For cleanersamples, we predict that the minimum conductivity depends strongly on $n_{\rmimp}$, increasing to $8 e^2/h$ for $n_{\rm imp} \sim 20 \times 10^{10}{\rmcm}^{-2}$. A clear strategy to improve graphene mobility is to eliminatecharged impurities or use a substrate with a larger dielectric constant.

direct_prompt: We derive the effective Lindblad operators for the non-Markovian decoherence and design a CQEC code to correct these errors. We show that our scheme can effectively suppress the decoherence effects and improve the performance of quantum systems. Our work provides a new approach for protecting quantum systems from non-Markovian decoherence and has potential applications in quantum information processing and quantum communication.The paper is organized as follows. In Section II, we introduce the basic concepts of CQEC and non-Markovian decoherence. In Section III, we derive the effective Lindblad operators for the non-Markovian decoherence. human_text: We show that for sufficiently largeerror-correction rates, the encoded state approximately follows an evolution ofthe type of a single decohering qubit, but with an effectively decreasedcoupling constant. Thequadratic enhancement depends on the existence of a Zeno regime in theHamiltonian evolution which is absent in purely Markovian dynamics. We analyzethe range of validity of this result and identify two relevant time scales.Finally, we extend the result to more general codes and argue that theperformance of continuous error correction will exhibit the same qualitativecharacteristics.

direct_prompt: Web data modeling for integration in data warehousesAbstract: This paper presents a methodology to model and integrate Web data into a data warehouse. The methodology consists of three main phases: (1) data extraction from Web sources, (2) data modeling and integration, and (3) data warehousing. In the first phase, data is extracted from Web sources using a wrapper induction tool. In the second phase, the extracted data is modeled using an extended entity-relationship (EER) model. The EER model is then transformed into a relational schema. In the third phase, the relational schema is used to create a data warehouse. The methodology is illustrated through a case study of a data warehouse for a travel agency. The case study demonstrates that the methodology is effective in modeling and integrating Web data into a data warehouse.
human_text: In a data warehousing process, the data preparation phase is crucial.Mastering this phase allows substantial gains in terms of time and performancewhen performing a multidimensional analysis or using data mining algorithms.Furthermore, a data warehouse can require external data. The web is a prevalentdata source in this context, but the data broadcasted on this medium are veryheterogeneous. We propose in this paper a UML conceptual model for a complexobject representing a superclass of any useful data source (databases, plaintexts, HTML and XML documents, images, sounds, video clips...). The translationinto a logical model is achieved with XML, which helps integrating all thesediverse, heterogeneous data into a unified format, and whose schema definitionprovides first-rate metadata in our data warehousing context.

We first provide an overview of the historical context and significance of Pappus's theorem, before delving into the technical details of our proof. Our method involves the use of a specific type of algebraic object, known as a differenced polynomial, which allows us to reduce the complexity of the proof and provide a clearer and more intuitive understanding of the underlying mathematical concepts. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach by walking the reader through a series of illustrative examples and providing a detailed analysis of the resulting computations.

direct_prompt: This study aims to model the clumping-induced polarimetric variability of hot star winds, which is an important aspect of understanding the behavior of these winds and their impact on the surrounding environment. Previous studies have shown that clumping in hot star winds can lead to significant variations in the observed polarization, but the physical mechanisms behind this phenomenon are not yet well understood. Using a combination of observations and simulations, we investigate the relationship between clumping and polarization in hot star winds and develop a model to predict the polarimetric variability of these winds. Our results show that clumping plays a key role in the observed polarization, and that the developed model can accurately predict the polarimetric variability of hot star winds.
human_text: Through the useof an analytic wind clumping model, we predict the time evolution of the linearpolarimetry over a large parameter space. We concentrate on the Luminous BlueVariables, which display the greatest amount of polarimetric variability andfor which we recently conducted a spectropolarimetric survey. Our model resultsindicate that the observed level of polarimetric variability can be reproducedfor two regimes of parameter space: one of a small number of massive,optically-thick clumps; and one of a very large number of low-mass clumps.Although a systematic time-resolved monitoring campaign is required todistinguish between the two scenarios, we currently favour the latter, giventhe short timescale of the observed polarization variability. As thepolarization is predicted to scale linearly with mass-loss rate, we anticipatethat all hot stars with very large mass-loss rates should display polarimetricvariability.

direct_prompt: In this study, we investigate the higher-order angular galaxy correlations in the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) using a sample of over 200,000 galaxies. We focus on the redshift and color dependence of the non-linear bias, which describes the deviation of the galaxy distribution from a random distribution. We measure the non-linear bias using a suite of statistics, including the bispectrum, trispectrum, and higher-order spectra. Our results showthat the non-linear bias is strongly dependent on both redshift and color, with greater deviations from randomness observed at higher redshift and for galaxies with redder colors. We interpret our findings in the context of current models of galaxy formation and evolution, and discuss the implications for future large-scale structure surveys.
human_text: Using models derived from theoreticalpower-spectra and perturbation theory, we measure the bias parameters $b_1$ and$c_2$, finding that the large differences in both bias parameters ($b_1$ and$c_2$) between early- and late-type galaxies are robust against changes inredshift, luminosity, and $\sigma_8$, and that both terms are consistentlysmaller for late-type galaxies. By directly comparing their higher-ordercorrelation measurements, we find large differences in the clustering oflate-type galaxies at redshifts lower than 0.3 and those at redshifts higherthan 0.3, both at large scales ($c_2$ is larger by $\sim0.5$ at $z > 0.3$) andsmall scales (large amplitudes are measured at small scales only for $z > 0.3$,suggesting much more merger driven star formation at $z > 0.3$). Finally, ourmeasurements of $c_2$ suggest both that $\sigma_8 < 0.8$ and $c_2$ is negative.

human_text: The electronic structure of the quasi-lowdimensional vanadium sulfide \bavs3is investigated for the different phases above the magnetic orderingtemperature. By means of density functional theory and its combination withdynamical-mean field theory, we follow the evolution of the relevant low-energyelectronic states on cooling. Hence we go in the metallic regime from the roomtemperature hexagonal phase to the orthorhombic phase after the firststructural transition, and close with the monoclinic insulating phase below themetal-insulator transition. Due to the low symmetry and expected intersitecorrelations, the latter phase is treated within cellular dynamical mean-fieldtheory. It is generally discussed how the intriguing interplay betweenband-structure and strong-correlation effects leads to the stabilization of thevarious electronic phases with decreasing temperature.

direct_prompt: In this study, we present the results of hydrodynamical simulations of the jet in the symbiotic star MWC 560, a system consisting of a white dwarf and a mass-losing red giant. The jet is thought to be launched from the white dwarf and interacts with the surrounding material, producing X-rays. We use a 2D axisymmetric hydrodynamics code to model the jet and its interaction with the environment, and compare the results to X-ray observations of MWC 560. Our simulations show that the jet is able to propagate through the surrounding material and produce X-ray emission, consistent with observations. We also find that the jet's interaction with the red giant's wind produces a turbulent, multi-component flow that can contribute to the observed X-ray variability.
human_text: We have focused our study on the total X-ray luminosity andits temporal variability, the resulting spectra and the spatial distribution ofthe emission. Temperature and density maps from our hydrodynamical simulationswith radiative cooling presented in the second paper are used together withemissivities calculated with the atomic database ATOMDB. The jets in our modelsshow extended and variable X-ray emission which can be characterized as a sumof hot and warm components with temperatures that are consistent withobservations of CH Cyg and R Aqr. The X-ray spectra of our model jets showemission line features which correspond to observed features in the spectra ofCH Cyg. The innermost parts of our pulsed jets show iron line emission in the6.4 - 6.7 keV range which may explain such emission from the central source inR Aqr.

direct_prompt: This paper presents a simulation study on the charging dynamics of ASTROD I, a spacecraft designed for long-term deep space missions. direct_prompt: The statistical properties of dust far-infrared emission are investigated in this study, with a focus on the physical processes that govern their behavior.
