The main results are the following. 1) Thecirrus noise level as a function of brightness has been previouslyoverestimated. It is found to be proportional to <I> instead of <I>^1.5, where<I> is the local average brightness at 100 micron. This scaling is inaccordance with the fact that the brightness fluctuation level observed at agiven angular scale on the sky is the sum of fluctuations of increasingamplitude with distance on the line of sight.

direct_prompt: Our sample consists of 24 T Tauri stars with known spectral types and circumstellar disks. direct_prompt: The Low Frequency Sensitivity to Gravitational Waves for ASTRODThe ASTROD (Advanced Surveillance and Tracking Radar for Orbital Debris) system is a cutting-edge radar system designed to detect and track orbital debris in Earth's orbit. In this study, we investigate the low frequency sensitivity of ASTROD for detecting gravitational waves. We analyze the system's frequency response and assess its ability to detect gravitational waves in the frequency range of 10^-4 to 10^-3 Hz. Our results show that ASTROD exhibits high sensitivity in this frequency range, making it a promising tool for detecting gravitational waves from sources such as supermassive black hole binaries and cosmic strings. We also discuss the implications of our findings for future gravitational wave observatories and highlight the potential of ASTROD for advancing our understanding of the universe.

One ofits main purposes is to detect gravitational waves sensitive to low-frequencyband similar to LISA, but shifted to lower frequencies. In this aspect, ASTRODwould complement LISA in probing the Universe and study strong-field black holephysics. Since ASTROD will be after LISA, in the Cosmic Vision time-frame2015-2025, a ten-fold improvement over LISA accelerometer noise goal would bepossible, allowing us to test relativistic gravity to 1 ppb and improve thegravitational-wave sensitivity. In this paper, we address to this possibleimprovement, especially in the frequency range below 0.1 mHz. We look intopossible thermal noise improvement, magnetic noise improvement, spuriousdischarging noise improvement and local gravitational noise improvement. Wediscuss various possibilities of lower-frequency gravitational-wave responsesand their significance to potential astrophysical sources.

direct_prompt: In this paper, we explore the relationship between modules over operads and functors. We begin by introducing the concept of a module over an operad, which is a way of extending the traditional notion of a module over a ring to the context of operads. We then examine the relationship between modules over operads and functors, showing that there is a natural correspondence between the two. We also discuss the properties of this correspondence, including its behavior under composition and its relationship to the forgetful functor. Finally, we explore some of the applications of this correspondence, including its use in the study of algebraic geometry and homotopy theory.
human_text: In the theory of operads we consider functors of generalized symmetric powersdefined by sums of coinvariant modules under actions of symmetric groups. Oneobserves classically that the construction of symmetric functors provides anisomorphism from the category of symmetric modules to a subcategory of thecategory of functors on the base category. The purpose of this book is toobtain a similar relationship for functors on a category of algebras over anoperad. We observe that right modules over operads, symmetric modules equipped with aright operad action, give rise to functors on categories of algebras and weprove that this construction yields an embedding of categories. Then we checkthat right modules over operads form a model category. In addition we provethat weak-equivalences of right modules correspond to pointwiseweak-equivalences at the functor level.

direct_prompt: This article presents a theoretical investigation of enhanced second-harmonic generation via the quadrupole-dipole hybrid exciton. Utilizing a combination of analytical and numerical methods, we examine the mechanism of second-harmonic generation in a quadrupole-dipole hybrid system and demonstrate a significant enhancement in the second-harmonic signal compared to traditional dipole-dipole systems. Our results show that the quadrupole-dipole interaction gives rise to a novel type of exciton, which exhibits a strong coupling between the quadrupole and dipole moments. This hybrid exciton leads to a substantial increase in the second-harmonic generation efficiency, making it a promising candidate for applications in nonlinear optical devices. Our findings have important implications for the development of novel nonlinear optical materials and devices, and may pave the way for new opportunities in fields such as high-powered laser technology and frequency conversion.
human_text: We report calculated substantial enhancement of the second harmonicgeneration (SHG) in cuprous oxide crystals resonantly hybridized with anappropriate organic material (DCM2:CA:PS 'solid-state solvent'). The quadrupoleorigin of the inorganic part of the quadrupole-dipole hybrid provides inversionsymmetry breaking and the organic part contributes to the oscillator strengthof the hybrid. We show that the enhancement of the SHG, compared to bulkcuprous oxide crystal, is proportional to the ratio of the DCM2 dipole momentand the effective dipole moment of the quadrupole transitions in the cuprousoxide. It is also inversely proportional to the line-width of the hybrid andbulk excitons. The enhancement may be regulated by adjusting the organic blend(mutual concentration of the DCM2 and CA part of the solvent) and pumpingconditions(varying the angle of incidence in case of optical pumping orpopulating the minimum of the lower branch of the hybrid in case of electricalpumping).

direct_prompt: In this article, we explore the possibility of holographic electroweak symmetry breaking from D-branes. We present a novel framework for understanding the interplay between holography and electroweak symmetry breaking, and demonstrate how D-branes can be used to mediate the breaking of this symmetry. Our results provide new insights into the relationship between holography and the electroweak force, and open up new avenues for exploring the phenomenology of electroweak symmetry breaking. We also discuss the potential implications of our findings for future experiments and observations. Finally, we conclude by highlighting the outstanding questions and future directions for research in this exciting area.

The benefit of holographic models based on D-brane configurations isthat both sides of the holographic duality are well understood. We find thatthe lightest technicolor resonances contribute negatively to thePeskin-Takeuchi S-parameter, but heavy resonances do not decouple and leadgenerically to large, positive values of S, consistent with standard estimatesin QCD-like theories. We study how the S parameter and the masses and decayconstants of the vector and axial-vector techni-resonances vary over aone-parameter family of D8-brane configurations. direct_prompt: In this study, we investigate the gas-grain chemistry in cold interstellar cloud cores using a microscopic Monte Carlo approach to surface chemistry. We focus on the role of grain surfaces in the chemistry of cold clouds, where the temperature is below 30 K and the pressure is around 10^4 Pa. The gas-grain interactions are simulated using a microscopic Monte Carlo method that resolves the surface structure of the grains and the reactivity of the adsorbates.Our results show that the grain surface chemistry plays a crucial role in determining the abundance and distribution of gas-phase species in cold clouds. We find that the grain surfaces act as a reservoir for certain species, such as CO, which can be released into the gas phase through thermal desorption.
human_text: AIM: We have recently developed a microscopic Monte Carlo approach to studysurface chemistry on interstellar grains and the morphology of ice mantles. Themethod is designed to eliminate the problems inherent in the rate-equationformalism to surface chemistry. Here we report the first use of this method ina chemical model of cold interstellar cloud cores that includes both gas-phaseand surface chemistry. The surface chemical network consists of a small numberof diffusive reactions that can produce molecular oxygen, water, carbondioxide, formaldehyde, methanol and assorted radicals. METHOD: The simulationis started by running a gas-phase model including accretion onto grains but nosurface chemistry or evaporation. The starting surface consists of either flator rough olivine. We introduce the surface chemistry of the three species H, Oand CO in an iterative manner using our stochastic technique.

direct_prompt: This study utilizes the Submillimeter Array (SMA) to detect and analyze the 658 GHz vibrationally-excited water masers in the vicinity of star-forming regions. The high-resolution observations provided by the SMA allow for the first time to investigate the properties of these masers in great detail. The data reveal a rich structure of the water masers, including multiple components and velocity gradients, which imply a complex physical environment. The study finds that the water masers are associated with outflows and shocks, which are likely driven by the activity of young stellar objects. The results suggest that the water masers may serve as a valuable tool for probing the physics of star formation and the properties of the interstellar medium.
human_text: Discovered in 1995 at the Caltech Submillimeter Observatory (CSO), thevibrationally-excited water maser line at 658 GHz (455 micron) is seen inoxygen-rich giant and supergiant stars. Because this maser can be so strong (upto thousands of Janskys), it was very helpful during the commissioning phase ofthe highest frequency band (620-700 GHz) of the Submillimeter Array (SMA)interferometer. From late 2002 to early 2006, brief attempts were made tosearch for emission from additional sources beyond the original CSO survey.These efforts have expanded the source count from 10 to 16. The maser emissionappears to be quite compact spatially, as expected from theoreticalconsiderations; thus these objects can potentially be used as atmospheric phasecalibrators. Many of these objects also exhibit maser emission in thevibrationally-excited SiO maser at 215 GHz.

direct_prompt: This study aimed to investigate the growth variability of tumour cell clones in vitro using a quantitative approach. We cultured three different types of tumour cell lines (A, B, and C) in a controlled microenvironment and monitored their growth over a period of 10 days. The growth rates of individual cell clones were measured using a spectrophotometer, and their variability was analysed using statistical methods. Our results showed that the growth rates of tumour cell clones varied significantly among different cell lines, with cell line A exhibiting the fastest growth rate and cell line C showing the slowest growth rate. We also observed that the growth rates of individual cell clones within each cell line were highly variable, with some clones exhibiting rapid growth while others showed slow growth.
human_text: The growth rate of each clonalpopulation has been estimated by fitting experimental data with the logisticequation. Results: The growth rates were observed to vary among differentclones. Up to six clones with a growth rate above or below the mean growth rateof the parent population were further cloned and the growth rates of theiroffsprings were measured. The distribution of the growth rates of the subclonesdid not significantly differ from that of the parent population thus suggestingthat growth variability has an epigenetic origin. To explain the observeddistributions of clonal growth rates we have developed a probabilistic modelassuming that the fluctuations in the number of mitochondria through successivecell cycles are the leading cause of growth variability. For fitting purposes,we have estimated experimentally by flow cytometry the maximum average numberof mitochondria in Molt3 cells.

direct_prompt: This article presents a lattice QCD calculation of light quark masses using the unquenched theory. The study employs a high-precision lattice action and a large dataset of configurations to determine the masses of up, down, and strange quarks. The results are compared to earlier quenched and unquenched calculations, and the impact of sea quarks is investigated. The findings demonstrate a significant improvement in the accuracy of the quark mass values with the inclusion of sea quarks. The article provides valuable insights into the light quark sector and sets a new standard for future lattice QCD studies.
human_text: We calculate the light meson spectrum and the light quark masses by latticeQCD simulation, treating all light quarks dynamically and employing the Iwasakigluon action and the nonperturbatively O(a)-improved Wilson quark action. Thecalculations are made at the squared lattice spacings at an equal distancea^2~0.005, 0.01 and 0.015 fm^2, and the continuum limit is taken assuming anO(a^2) discretization error. The light meson spectrum is consistent withexperiment. The up, down and strange quark masses in the \bar{MS} scheme at 2GeV are \bar{m}=(m_{u}+m_{d})/2=3.55^{+0.65}_{-0.28} MeV andm_s=90.1^{+17.2}_{-6.1} MeV where the error includes statistical and allsystematic errors added in quadrature. These values contain the previousestimates obtained with the dynamical u and d quarks within the error.

direct_prompt: This study investigates the occurrence of exoplanets around three intermediate-mass subgiant stars, specifically those with retired A-type stars as companions. Intermediate-mass subgiants are stars with masses between 2.3 and 5 solar masses that have evolved from the main sequence and are now in the subgiant branch stage. The study uses a combination of radial velocity and transit photometry observations to detect exoplanets orbiting these stars. The results show that all three stars have planetary systems, with a total of five exoplanets discovered. The planets are gas giants with masses ranging from 0.5 to 1.3 Jupiter masses and orbital periods between 20 and 100 days. The presence of retired A-type stars as companions to these subgiants suggests that the planets may have undergone tidal migrations, leading to their close-in orbits.
human_text: All three stars show variability in theirradial velocities consistent with planet-mass companions in Keplerian orbits.We find a planet with a minimum mass of 2.5 Mjup in a 351.5 day orbit around HD192699, a planet with a minimum mass of 2.0 Mjup in a 341.1 day orbit around HD210702, and a planet with a minimum mass of 0.61 Mjup in a 297.3 day orbitaround HD 175541. Stellar mass estimates from evolutionary models indicate thatall of these stars were formerly A-type dwarfs with masses ranging from 1.65 to1.85 Msun. These three long-period planets would not have been detectableduring their stars' main-sequence phases due to the large rotational velocitiesand stellar jitter exhibited by early-type dwarfs. There are now 9 "retired"(evolved) A-type stars (Mstar > 1.6 Msun) with known planets.

direct_prompt: In this article, we propose a novel mechanism for adaptive growth rate regulation, which can be applied to various biological systems. The proposed mechanism utilizes a generic signaling pathway that regulates cell growth and division, allowing for adaptive adjustments to growth rates in response to changing environmental conditions. This pathway integrates signals from multiple sources, including nutrient availability, cell density, and environmental stressors, to modulate cell growth and proliferation. The mechanism can be tuned to different cell types and growth conditions, enabling optimal growth rates for various biological systems. We demonstrate the efficacy of this mechanism through simulations and experiments using E. coli as a model organism. Our results show that the proposed mechanism can effectively regulate growth rates in response to changing environmental conditions, resulting in improved cellular performance and robustness.
human_text: Weshow that for any growing cells whose gene expression is under stochasticfluctuations, adaptive cellular state is inevitably selected by noise, evenwithout specific signal transduction network for it. In general, changes inprotein concentration in a cell are given by its synthesis minus dilution anddegradation, both of which are proportional to the rate of cell growth. In anadaptive state with a higher growth speed, both terms are large and balanced.Under the presence of noise in gene expression, the adaptive state is lessaffected by stochasticity since both the synthesis and dilution terms arelarge, while for a non-adaptive state both the terms are smaller so that cellsare easily kicked out of the original state by noise. Hence, escape time from acellular state and the cellular growth rate are negatively correlated.

direct_prompt: In this study, we investigate the Larkin-Imry-Ma (LIM) state of 3He-A in aerogel using nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy. The 3He-A nucleus in aerogel exhibits a unique nuclear spin dynamics that is not observed in other spin-1/2 systems, which we attribute to the ultralow temperature and high porosity of the aerogel matrix. Our results provide new insights into the LIM state of 3He-A and its potential applications in quantum computing and spintronics. This work demonstrates the versatility of NMR spectroscopy for studying quantum phenomena in novel materials and paves the way for further investigations into the properties of 3He-A in aerogel.
human_text: Superfluid 3He-A shares the properties of spin nematic and chiral orbitalferromagnet. Its order parameter is characterized by two vectors d and l. Thisdoubly anisotropic superfluid, when it is confined in aerogel, represents themost interesting example of a system with continuous symmetry in the presenceof random anisotropy disorder. We discuss the Larkin-Imry-Ma state, which ischaracterized by the short-range orientational order of the vector l, while thelong-range orientational order is destroyed by the collective action of therandomly oriented aerogel strings. On the other hand, sufficiently largeregular anisotropy produced either by the deformation of the aerogel or byapplied superflow suppresses the Larkin-Imry-Ma effect leading to the uniformorientation of the vector l. This interplay of regular and random anisotropyallows us to study many different effects.

direct_prompt: This paper presents a novel approach to distributed source coding over a network, with a focus on minimizing the cost of transmission. Our proposed method leverages advanced compression techniques and network coding strategies to achieve significant reductions in transmission costs, while maintaining high levels of data quality and accuracy. Through simulations and theoretical analysis, we demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach and show that it outperforms traditional methods in terms of cost and performance. Our findings have important implications for a wide range of applications, including multimedia streaming, wireless sensor networks, and distributed data storage systems. Furthermore, our approach is designed to be scalable and adaptable to various network configurations, making it a valuable contribution to the field of distributed source coding.
human_text: This work considers the problem of transmitting multiple compressible sourcesover a network at minimum cost. The aim is to find the optimal rates at whichthe sources should be compressed and the network flows using which they shouldbe transmitted so that the cost of the transmission is minimal. We considernetworks with capacity constraints and linear cost functions. The problem iscomplicated by the fact that the description of the feasible rate region ofdistributed source coding problems typically has a number of constraints thatis exponential in the number of sources. This renders general purpose solversinefficient. We present a framework in which these problems can be solvedefficiently by exploiting the structure of the feasible rate regions coupledwith dual decomposition and optimization techniques such as the subgradientmethod and the proximal bundle method.

direct_prompt: In this study, we examine the relationship between molecular line intensities and cloud masses in various galaxy types. We present a new method for determining conversion factors that enable the estimation of cloud masses from molecular line intensities. Our approach is based on a detailed analysis of the physical conditions within molecular clouds and takes into account the different excitation mechanisms of molecular lines in different galaxy types. We derive conversion factors for three specific galaxy types: spiral, elliptical, and irregular galaxies. Our results show that the conversion factors vary significantly between galaxy types, highlighting the importance of considering the specific galaxy environment when using molecular line intensities as a proxy for cloud masses. We demonstrate the applicability of our method using a sample of galaxies with well-known molecular line intensities and cloud masses.
human_text: We present theoretically-established values of the CO-to-H2 and C-to-H2conversion factors that may be used to estimate the gas masses of externalgalaxies. We consider four distinct galaxy types, represented by M51, NGC 6946,M82 and SMC N27. The physical parameters that best represent the conditionswithin the molecular clouds in each of the galaxy types are estimated using achi^2 analysis of several observed atomic fine structure and CO rotationallines. This analysis is explored over a wide range of density, radiation field,extinction, and other relevant parameters. Using these estimated physicalconditions in methods that we have previously established, CO-to-H2 conversionfactors are then computed for CO transitions up to J=9-8. For the conventionalCO(1-0) transition, the computed conversion factor varies significantly belowand above the canonical value for the Milky Way in the four galaxy typesconsidered.

direct_prompt: In this study, we investigate the colour selection of distant galaxies in the UKIDSS Ultra-Deep Survey Early Data Release. We aim to explore the efficiency of different colour selection techniques in identifying high-redshift galaxies. Our analysis reveals that the traditional colour-colour selection method is effective in selecting galaxies at redshift z ≈ 2, but becomes increasingly incomplete at higher redshifts. We propose a new colour selection criterion that combines the optical-to-near-infrared colour ratio with the 4000 Å break strength, which shows improved efficiency in identifying high-redshift galaxies. Our results suggest that this new criterion can be used to identify galaxies up to redshift z ≈ 6. We also demonstrate that the proposed criterion is less susceptible to contamination from lower-redshift interlopers.
human_text: Combined with very deepSubaru optical photometry, the depth (K_AB = 22.5) and area (0.62 deg^2) of theUDS EDR allows us to investigate optical/near-IR selection using a large sampleof over 30,000 objects. By using the B-z, z-K colour-colour diagram (the BzKtechnique) we identify over 7500 candidate galaxies at z > 1.4, which can befurther separated into passive and starforming systems (pBzK and sBzKrespectively). Our unique sample allows us to identify a new feature notpreviously seen in BzK diagrams, consistent with the passively evolving trackof early type galaxies at z < 1.4. We also compare the BzK technique with theR-K colour selection of Extremely Red Objects (EROs) and the J-K selection ofDistant Red Galaxies (DRGs), and quantify the overlap between thesepopulations. We find that the majority of DRGs, at these relatively brightmagnitudes are also EROs.

direct_prompt: In this study, we investigate the basic principles of postgrowth annealing of CdTe:Cl ingots to obtain semi-insulating crystals. We explore the effects of annealing temperature, time, and atmosphere on the structural and optical properties of the CdTe:Cl crystals. Our results show that appropriate annealing conditions can lead to the formation of high-quality semi-insulating crystals with improved optical properties. We also discuss the potential applications of these semi-insulating crystals in various electronic devices. Furthermore, we present a detailed analysis of the underlying mechanisms of postgrowth annealing, providing insights into the thermally activated processes that govern the formation of semi-insulating crystals.
human_text: The process of annealing of a CdTe:Cl ingot during its cooling after growthwas studied. The annealing was performed in two stages: a high-temperaturestage, with an approximate equality of chlorine and cadmium vacancyconcentrations established at the thermodynamic equilibrium between the crystaland vapors of volatile components, and a low-temperature stage, with chargeddefects interacting to form neutral associations. The chlorine concentrationsnecessary to obtain semi-insulating crystals were determined for various ingotcooling rates in the high temperature stage. The dependence of the chlorineconcentration [Cl+Te] in the ingot on the temperature of annealing in thehigh-temperature stage was found. The carrier lifetimes and drift mobilitieswere obtained in relation to the temperature and cadmium vapor pressure in thepostgrowth annealing of the ingot.

direct_prompt: In this study, we investigate the effect of edge oxidation on the electronic properties of zigzag graphene nanoribbons (ZGNRs), particularly the half-metallicity. Using first-principles density functional theory calculations, we find that edge oxidation significantly enhances the half-metallicity of ZGNRs, leading to a larger spin polarization and a higher magnetic moment. The edge oxidation also introduces defects into the ZGNRs, which affects their electronic structure and magnetic properties. We observe that the edge-oxidized ZGNRs exhibit a unique electronic structure, characterized by a large gap at the Dirac points, which is absent in pristine ZGNRs. The enhanced half-metallicity in edge-oxidized ZGNRs makes them promising candidates for applications in spintronics and other emerging technologies. Finally, we discuss the potential challenges and opportunities of using edge-oxidized ZGNRs in real-world applications.
human_text: We present a novel comprehensive first-principles theoretical study of theelectronic properties and relative stabilities of edge-oxidized zigzag graphenenanoribbons. The oxidation schemes considered include hydroxyl, carboxyl,ether, and ketone groups. Using screened exchange density functional theory, weshow that these oxidized ribbons are more stable than hydrogen-terminatednanoribbons except for the case of the etheric groups. The stable oxidizedconfigurations maintain a spin-polarized ground state with antiferromagneticordering localized at the edges, similar to the fully hydrogenatedcounterparts. More important, edge oxidation is found to lower the onsetelectric field required to induce half-metallic behavior and extend the overallfield range at which the systems remain half-metallic. Once the half-metallicstate is reached, further increase of the external electric field intensityproduces a rapid decrease in the spin magnetization up to a point where themagnetization is quenched completely.

The findings of this research have significant implications for our understanding of the fundamental forces of nature and the structure of matter.
human_text: Unfortunately, theyare subject to large hadronic uncertainties present in epsilon'/epsilon, whosetheoretical prediction in the Standard Model (SM) is reviewed and updated here.With the matrix elements of Q_6 (gluon penguin) and Q_8 (electroweak penguin)evaluated in the large-N limit and m_s^MS(2 GeV) = 100 MeV from lattice QCD,(epsilon'/epsilon)_SM turns out to be close to the data so that significantdepartures of Br(K_L -> pi^0 nu {bar nu}) and Br(K_L -> pi^0 l^+ l^-) from theSM expectations are unlikely, while Br(K^+ -> pi^+ nu {bar nu}) can be enhancedeven by a factor 5. On the other hand, modest departures of the relevanthadronic matrix elements from their large-N values allow for a consistentdescription of epsilon'/epsilon within the LHT model accompanied by largeenhancements of Br(K_L -> pi^0 nu {bar nu}) and Br(K_L -> pi^0 l^+ l^-), butonly modest enhancements of Br(K^+ -> pi^+ nu {bar nu}).

direct_prompt: In this article, we present a novel approach to studying the effective Lagrangian for the $\chi^{+}_j \chi^{-}_kH^{0}_l$ interaction in the minimal supersymmetric standard model (MSSM). By employing a combination of analytical and numerical techniques, we derive new expressions for the Wilson coefficients of the relevant operators, and demonstrate their application in the study of neutral Higgs decays. Our results provide valuable insights into the phenomenology of the MSSM Higgs sector, and pave the way for further investigations into the properties of the $H^{0}_l$ boson. The Article is organized as follows: in Section II, we introduce the theoretical framework and define the notation used throughout the paper. In Section III, we present our results for the Wilson coefficients, while Section IV is devoted to the phenomenological analysis of neutral Higgs decays.
human_text: We extend previous analyses of the supersymmetric loop correction to theneutral Higgs couplings to include the coupling $\chi^{+}_j \chi^{-}_kH^{0}_l$.The analysis completes the previous analyses where similar corrections werecomputed for the $\bar{\tau} \tau H^{0}_l$, $\bar{b} b H^{0}_l$, $\bar{c} cH^{0}_l$ and for $\bar{t} t H^{0}_l$ couplings within the minimalsupersymmetric standard model. The effective one loop Lagrangian is thenapplied to the computation of the neutral Higgs decays. The sizes of thesupersymmetric loop corrections of the neutral Higgs decay widths into$\chi^{+}_i \chi^{-}_j$ ($i=1,2$; $j=1,2$) are investigated and thesupersymmetric loop correction is found to be in the range of $7\sim15%$ insignificant regions of the parameter space. By including the loop correctionsof the other decay channels $\bar{b} b$, $\bar{t} t$, $\bar{\tau} \tau$,$\bar{c} c$, and $\chi^0_i \chi^0_j$ ($i=1-4$; $j=1-4$), the corrections tobranching ratios for $H^{0}_l\to \chi^{+}_i \chi^{-}_j$ can reach as high as40%.

direct_prompt: The authors argue that the traditional focus on species richness alone is insufficient for understanding the long-term evolutionary success of a clade. Instead, they propose a new metric, phylogenetic diversity, which takes into account the evolutionary relationships between species. Using a combination of theoretical models and empirical data, the authors demonstrate that species that are phylogenetically diverse are more likely to contribute to the future diversity of a clade. They suggest that this metric can be used to identify species that are critical for the long-term evolutionary success of a group, and to inform conservation efforts. The authors conclude that by "hedging our bets" and investing in a diverse range of species, we can ensure the continued evolutionary success of life on Earth.
human_text: If predictions for species extinctions hold, then the `tree of life' todaymay be quite different to that in (say) 100 years. We describe a technique toquantify how much each species is likely to contribute to future biodiversity,as measured by its expected contribution to phylogenetic diversity. Ourapproach considers all possible scenarios for the set of species that will beextant at some future time, and weights them according to their likelihoodunder an independent (but not identical) distribution on species extinctions.Although the number of extinction scenarios can typically be very large, weshow that there is a simple algorithm that will quickly compute this index. Themethod is implemented and applied to the prosimian primates as a test case, andthe associated species ranking is compared to a related measure (the `Shapleyindex').

direct_prompt: In this article, we investigate the phenomenon of matter-wave interference in Fermi condensates, which are macroscopic quantum states of matter that occur at extremely low temperatures. We focus on s-wave and p-wave Fermi condensates, which are characterized by different types of pairwise interactions between the atoms. By manipulating the interactions between the atoms, we observe the emergence of matter-wave interference patterns, which are a result of the coherent superposition of the matter waves associated with each atomic species. Our results demonstrate the ability to control the phase relationships between the matter waves, leading to the formation of complex interference patterns that are sensitive to the symmetry of the interactions. These findings have important implications for the study of quantum phenomena in many-body systems and the development of new quantum technologies.
human_text: We discuss the time evolution and matter-wave interference of Fermicondensates on the BEC side of Feshbach resonances for s and p-wavesuperfluids, upon release from harmonic traps. In swave systems, where theorder parameter is a complex scalar, we find that the interference patternsdepend on the relative phase of the order parameters of the condensates. Inp-wave systems involving the mixture of two-hyperfine states, we show that theinterference pattern exhibits a polarization effect depending on the relativeorientation of the two vector order parameters. Lastly, we also point out thatp-wave Fermi condensates exhibit an anisotropic expansion, reflecting thespatial anisotropy of the underlying interaction between fermions and theorbital nature of the vector order parameter. Potential applications of ourresults include systems of ultra-cold atoms that exhibit p-wave Feshbachresonances such as 6Li or 40K.

direct_prompt: Utilizing a sample of 20 quasars with redshifts between 2.5 and 4.5, the study examines the relations between black hole mass, host galaxy mass, and star formation rate. The results indicate that black holes and their host spheroids grow in tandem, with the black hole mass being a constant fraction of the host galaxy mass. The authors suggest that this correlation is likely due to the self-regulation of feedback mechanisms. Furthermore, the study finds that the star formation rate in these quasars is suppressed compared to that in non-active galaxies, indicating that the quasar activity may play a role in regulating star formation in the host galaxy. Overall, these findings provide new insights into the co-evolution of black holes and their host galaxies in the early universe.
human_text: We study the growth of black holes and stellar population in spheroids athigh redshift using several (sub)mm-loud QSO samples. Applying the samecriteria established in an earlier work, we find that, similar to IR QSOs atlow redshift, the far-infrared emission of these (sub)mm-loud QSOs mainlyoriginates from dust heated by starbursts. By combining low-z IR QSOs andhigh-z (sub)mm-loud QSOs, we find a trend that the star formation rate($\Mstardot$) increases with the accretion rate ($\Mdot$). We compare thevalues of $\Mstardot/\Mdot$ for submm emitting galaxies (SMGs), far-infraredultraluminous/hyperluminous QSOs and typical QSOs, and construct a likelyevolution scenario for these objects. direct_prompt: Pulsar radiation belts and transient radio emission are two distinct phenomena that have been observed in the vicinity of pulsars, rapidly rotating and strongly magnetized neutron stars. Pulsar radiation belts refer to the regions around a pulsar where high-energy particles are energized by the strong magnetic field and curvature of the magnetic field lines. These particles can emit radiation across the electromagnetic spectrum, from radio waves to gamma rays. Transient radio emission, on the other hand, refers to short-lived bursts of radio waves that are often observed coming from pulsars. These bursts are thought to be caused by sudden changes in the pulsar's magnetosphere, such as a sparking event or a burst of plasma. Both pulsar radiation belts and transient radio emission offer valuable insights into the physics of pulsars and their surrounding environments.

In the belts located in the closed field line region near thelight cylinder relativistic pairs are trapped and maintained at a densitysubstantially higher than the local Goldreich-Julian corotation density. Thetrapped plasma can be supplied and replenished by either direct injection ofrelativistic pairs from acceleration of externally-supplied particles in adormant outer gap or in situ ionization of the accreted neutral material in thetrapping region. The radiation belts can be disrupted by waves that are excitedin the region as the result of plasma instabilities or emitted from the surfacedue to starquakes or stellar oscillations. The disruption can cause anintermittent particle precipitation toward the star producing radio bursts.

direct_prompt: To address this issue, we propose a new approach that views quantum mechanics as a theory defined on a Hilbert manifold, which is a space of all possible states of a system. This approach allows for a more flexible and dynamic description of quantum systems, and it leads to the principle of functional relativity, which states that the laws of physics should be independent of the choice of background space-time. We demonstrate the utility of this approach by applying it to several examples, including the harmonic oscillator and the hydrogen atom. Our results show that the principle of functional relativity provides a powerful tool for understanding the behavior of quantum systems, and it has important implications for our understanding of the nature of space and time.

The principle offunctional relativity is introduced which states that quantum theory is indeeda functional tensor theory, i.e., it can be described by functional tensorequations. The main equations of quantum theory are shown to be compatible withthe principle of functional relativity. By accepting the principle as ahypothesis, we then analyze the origin of physical dimensions, provide ageometric interpretation of Planck's constant, and find a simple interpretationof the two-slit experiment and the process of measurement.

direct_prompt: We first present a model for the network structure, which captures the essential features of small-world networks, including short cuts and long-range connections. Our results show that the distance-dependent random links have a significant impact on the diffusion process, leading to faster and more efficient spreading compared to traditional small-world networks.We also find that the optimal frequency of long-range connections, which maximizes the diffusion rate, decreases as the distance between nodes increases.
human_text: It has been well-established thatin a large class of interacting systems, adding an arbitrarily small densityof, possibly long-range, quenched random links to a regular lattice interactiontopology, will give rise to mean-field (or annealed) like behavior. In somecases, however, mean-field scaling breaks down, such as in diffusion or in theEdwards-Wilkinson process in "low-dimensional" small-world networks. Thisbreak-down can be understood by treating the random links perturbatively, wherethe mean-field (or annealed) prediction appears as the lowest-order term of anaive perturbation expansion. The asymptotic analytic results are alsoconfirmed numerically by employing exact numerical diagonalization of thenetwork Laplacian. Further, we construct a finite-size scaling framework forthe relevant observables, capturing the cross-over behaviors in finitenetworks. This work provides a detailed account of theself-consistent-perturbative and renormalization approaches briefly introducedin two earlier short reports.

direct_prompt: We synthesize high-quality TiO2 nanoparticles and nanofilms using sol- gel and molecular beam epitaxy methods, respectively. direct_prompt: In this article, we propose a new space mission concept called LEAVITT, which aims to discover and characterize 10,000 transiting planets in the solar neighborhood using a MIDEX-class space telescope. The mission will utilize a unique exoplanet hunting strategy that combines high-cadence photometry with state-of-the-art machine learning algorithms to detect small, rocky planets in the habitable zones of nearby stars. The LEAVITT mission will provide valuable insights into the formation and evolution of planetary systems, as well as the potential for life to exist beyond Earth. The mission will also provide a wealth of new data that will enable further studies of stellar astrophysics, galaxy evolution, and cosmic microwave background astronomy. With its unprecedented precision and sensitivity, LEAVITT has the potential to make groundbreaking discoveries that will reshape our understanding of the universe.

Our survey will be all-sky and focused on stars brighterthan V=14.8. Down to V=12, LEAVITT will be able to detect Neptune-sizedobjects. Because of it's high cadence, LEAVITT is about 100 times moresensitive at detecting transits than GAIA, while it will find more than 20times as many transits as KEPLER. LEAVITT has multi-band photometric capabilityimplemented via a low-resolution dispersive element which can obtain 0.2% (2mmag) photometry down to V=14.8. LEAVITT's high multi-band photometric accuracyreduces the number of false-positives significantly.

direct_prompt: By analyzing a large trace dataset, we identify key features of P2P IPTV traffic and examine its scaling behavior using various techniques. Our results show that P2P IPTV traffic exhibits a power-law distribution in terms of session durations, and follows a stretched-exponential pattern in terms of packet inter-arrival times. We also find that the traffic displays a high degree of temporal and spatial locality, with a significant fraction of packets belonging to a few popular streams. Furthermore, we observe a strong correlation between the number of peers and the stream popularity, suggesting a hierarchical structure in the P2P overlay. Our findings have important implications for the design and optimization of P2P IPTV systems, and highlight the need for further research in understanding the underlying mechanisms and dynamics of this emerging technology.
human_text: Dur- ing the 2006 FIFAWorld Cup, we performed an extensive measurement campaign. From the collecteddata, we charac- terized the P2P IPTV traffic structure at different timescales by using wavelet based transform method. To the best of our knowledge,this is the first work, which presents a complete multiscale analysis of theP2P IPTV traffic. Our results show that the scaling properties of the TCPtraffic present periodic behavior whereas the UDP traffic is stationary andlead to long- range depedency characteristics. For all the applications, thedownload traffic has different characteristics than the upload traffic. Thesignaling traffic has a significant impact on the download traffic but it hasnegligible impact on the upload.

direct_prompt: By exploiting the group theory of classical groups, we establish that the character rings can be endowed with a Hopf algebra structure, enabling us to study their properties using techniques from algebraic combinatorics and representation theory. Specifically, we show that the character rings of orthogonal, symplectic, and unitary groups can be realized as certain quotients of the group algebra, thereby providing a concise representation of the Hopf algebra structure. Our results have far-reaching implications for the study of character rings and their connections to representation theory, geometry, and topology. Moreover, we demonstrate that the Hopf algebra structure of character rings can be employed to deriving results on the representation theory of classical groups, including the construction of irreducible representations and the computation of character values.
human_text: Here we study the character rings \CO and\CSp of the orthogonal and symplectic subgroups of the general linear groupwithin the same framework of symmetric functions. We show that \CO and \CSpalso admit natural Hopf algebra structures that are isomorphic to that of \CGL,and hence to \Sym. The isomorphisms are determined explicitly, along with thespecification of standard bases for \CO and \CSp analogous to those used for\Sym. A major structural change arising from the adoption of these bases is theintroduction of new orthogonal and symplectic Schur-Hall scalar products.Significantly, the adjoint with respect to multiplication no longer coincides,as it does in the \CGL case, with a Foulkes derivative or skew operation. Theadjoint and Foulkes derivative now require separate definitions, and theirproperties are explored here in the orthogonal and symplectic cases.

direct_prompt: This study investigates the rotation and activity of pre-main-sequence (PMS) stars, which are critical factors in their evolution and development. Using a large sample of PMS stars, we analyze their rotation periods, surface temperatures, and activity indicators, such as chromospheric Ca II H and K emission, to explore the relationships between these properties. Our results show that PMS stars exhibit a wide range of rotation periods, from less than 1 day to several weeks, and that slower rotators tend to have higher surface temperatures. We also find that chromospheric activity decreases with increasing age, indicating a gradual decline in magnetic activity as PMS stars mature. Moreover, we discover a correlation between rotation period and activity, suggesting that rapidly rotating stars are more active.

Our targets are 74 F-M dwarfs in the youngstellar associations Eta Cha, TW Hydrae, Beta Pic, and Tuc-Hor, spanning agesfrom 6 to 30 Myr. While the Halpha EW for most F and G stars are consistentwith pure photospheric absorption, most K and M stars show chromosphericemission. By comparing Halpha EW in our sample to results in the literature, wesee a clear evolutionary sequence: Chromospheric activity declines steadilyfrom the T Tauri phase to the main sequence. Using activity as an ageindicator, we find a plausible age range for the Tuc-Hor association of 10-40Myr.

direct_prompt: This study investigates the effectiveness of collaborative tagging systems in promoting vocabulary growth among users. Through a mixed-methods approach, we collected data from a sample of 100 participants who used a collaborative tagging system for a period of six weeks. Our results show a significant increase in vocabulary size and diversity among users who engaged in collaborative tagging, compared to those who did not. Additionally, we found that users who contributed more frequently to the tagging system exhibited higher levels of vocabulary growth. Our findings suggest that collaborative tagging systems can be a valuable tool for language learning and vocabulary development. Further research is needed to explore the long-term effects of collaborative tagging on vocabulary growth and to investigate the optimal conditions for its implementation.

We study the temporal evolution of the globalvocabulary size, i.e. the number of distinct tags in the entire system, as wellas the evolution of local vocabularies, that is the growth of the number ofdistinct tags used in the context of a given resource or user. In both cases,we find power-law behaviors with exponents smaller than one. Surprisingly, theobserved growth behaviors are remarkably regular throughout the entire historyof the system and across very different resources being bookmarked. Similarsub-linear laws of growth have been observed in written text, and thisqualitative universality calls for an explanation and points in the directionof non-trivial cognitive processes in the complex interaction patternscharacterizing collaborative tagging.

direct_prompt: The CERN Axion Solar Telescope (CAST) is a pioneering experiment aimed at detecting axions, hypothetical particles that could solve the solar neutrino problem. To enhance the sensitivity of CAST, a new detector based on P-type, neutrino-sensitive, charge-coupled devices (pn-CCDs) is being developed. This background study for the pn-CCD detector is crucial to understand and mitigate potential background sources that could hinder the detection of axions. We investigate various sources of background, including thermal radiation, cosmic rays, and intrinsic radioactivity, and outline strategies to minimize their impact. A thorough comprehension of the background will enable the pn-CCD detector to reach unprecedented sensitivity levels, paving the way for a potential discovery of axions.
human_text: The CERN Axion Solar Telescope (CAST) experiment searches for axions from theSun converted into photons with energies up to around 10 keV via the inversePrimakoff effect in the high magnetic field of a superconducting Large HadronCollider (LHC) prototype magnet. A backside illuminated pn-CCD detector inconjunction with an X-ray mirror optics is one of the three detectors used inCAST to register the expected photon signal. Since this signal is very rare anddifferent background components (environmental gamma radiation, cosmic rays,intrinsic radioactive impurities in the set-up, ...) entangle it, a detailedstudy of the detector background has been undertaken with the aim to understandand further reduce the background level of the detector. The analysis is basedon measured data taken during the Phase I of CAST and on Monte Carlosimulations of different background components.

direct_prompt: In this article, we investigate the existence and properties of noncomposite vortices in mesoscopic two-gap superconductors. We show that these vortices are thermodynamically stable and exhibit unique properties, such as a quantized circulating current and a topological charge that is robust against perturbations. Our results provide new insights into the behavior of noncomposite vortices in mesoscopic superconductors and may have potential applications in the development of new superconducting devices. Using a combination of analytical and numerical methods, we demonstrate the stability of these vortices and explore their properties in various regimes. Our findings contribute to a deeper understanding of the interplay between superconductivity and topology in mesoscopic systems.
human_text: In mesoscopic two-gap superconductors with sizes of the order of thecoherence length noncomposite vortices are found to be thermodynamically stablein a large domain of the $T - H$ phase diagram. In these phases the vortexcores of one condensate are spatially separated from the other condensate ones,and their respective distributions can adopt distinct symmetries. Theappearance of these vortex phases is caused by a non-negligible effect of theboundary of the sample on the superconducting order parameter and representstherefore a genuine mesoscopic effect. For low values of interband Josephsoncoupling vortex patterns with $L_1 \neq L_2$ can arise in addition to thephases with $L_1 =L_2$, where $L_1$ and $L_2$ are total vorticities in the twocondensates. The calculations show that noncomposite vortices could be observedin thin mesoscopic samples of MgB$_{2}$.

direct_prompt: The abstract is as follows:This research paper explores the infrared extinction law at extreme optical depths within a dark cloud core. The study employs data from the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) and the Submillimeter Array (SMA) to determine the infrared extinction law in the cloud's core. The analysis shows a departure from the standard extinction law, with an increased extinction rate at high optical depths. This departure is attributed to the presence of large dust grains and Ice mantles, which are abundant in the cloud's core. The study's results provide insights into the physical conditions and processes that govern the formation of dense molecular cloud cores. The findings also underscore the importance of considering the effects of dust grain size and ice mantles when modeling the extinction properties of dark clouds.

Consequently, there appears to beno significant variation of the extinction law with depth through the B59 lineof sight. However, when slopes are translated into the relative extinctioncoefficients A_\lambda/A_K, we find an extinction law which departs from thesimple extrapolation of the near-infrared power law extinction curve, andagrees more closely with a dust extinction model for a cloud with a total toselective absorption R_V=5.5 and a grain size distribution favoring largergrains than those in the diffuse ISM. direct_prompt: The energetics of positron states trapped at vacancies in solids have been studied using a combination of theoretical and experimental methods. The positron binding energy and annihilation rate have been found to be dependent on the type of solid and the vacancy concentration. For example, in diamond, the positron binding energy is 0.15 eV, while in silicon it is 0.43 eV. The annihilation rate is also affected by the crystal structure, with silicon having a slower annihilation rate than diamond. These findings have important implications for the development of positron-based materials and devices.
human_text: We report a computational first-principles study of positron trapping atvacancy defects in metals and semiconductors. The main emphasis is on theenergetics of the trapping process including the interplay between the positronstate and the defect's ionic structure and on the ensuing annihilationcharacteristics of the trapped state. For vacancies in covalent semiconductorsthe ion relaxation is a crucial part of the positron trapping process enablingthe localization of the positron state. However, positron trapping does notstrongly affect the characteristic features of the electronic structure, e.g.,the ionization levels change only moderately. Also in the case of metalvacancies the positron-induced ion relaxation has a noticeable effect on thecalculated positron lifetime and momentum distribution of annihilatingelectron-positron pairs.

The results show that the proposed approach achieves better QoS provisioning and improved resource utilization compared to state-of-the-art methods. direct_prompt: In this study, we investigate the critical current behavior of type-II superconductors in a broken Bose glass state. Through numerical simulations and analytical calculations, we demonstrate that the critical current in this state exhibits unique scaling behavior with temperature and magnetic field strength. Our results suggest that the critical current of type-II superconductors in a broken Bose glass state is significantly influenced by the underlying disorder. This research provides valuable insights into the unconventional superconducting properties of systems in the Bose glass phase. Overall, our findings contribute to a deeper understanding of the complex interplay between superconductivity and disorder in type-II superconductors.

It also indicates that the Bose glass state breaks into piecesalong the direction of the correlated pinning centers if the latter have finitelength. The critical current is predicted to crossover from two dimensional tothree dimensional behavior as a function of sample thickness along thecorrelated pinning centers in such case. direct_prompt: We provide a comprehensive analysis of the relationship between KK-theory and strongly self-absorbing C*-algebras, demonstrating the implications of self-absorption on the structure and properties of these algebras. Through our examination, we establish a framework for understanding the KK-theory of strongly self-absorbing C*-algebras and its applications in the study of operator algebras. Our results shed light on the connections between self-absorption, K-theory, and operator algebras, offering new insights into the interplay between these areas of research. Additionally, we investigate the classification and uniqueness properties of strongly self-absorbing C*-algebras within the framework of KK-theory, providing valuable contributions to the existing literature on this topic. Overall, our findings contribute to a deeper understanding of the KK-theory of strongly self-absorbing C*-algebras and their role in the broader context of operator algebras.
human_text: Let $\Dh$ and $A$ be unital and separable $C^{*}$-algebras; let $\Dh$ bestrongly self-absorbing. It is known that any two unital $^*$-homomorphismsfrom $\Dh$ to $A \otimes \Dh$ are approximately unitarily equivalent. We showthat, if $\Dh$ is also $K_{1}$-injective, they are even asymptoticallyunitarily equivalent. This in particular implies that any unital endomorphismof $\Dh$ is asymptotically inner. Moreover, the space of automorphisms of $\Dh$is compactly-contractible (in the point-norm topology) in the sense that forany compact Hausdorff space $X$, the set of homotopy classes $[X,\Aut(\Dh)]$reduces to a point. The respective statement holds for the space of unitalendomorphisms of $\Dh$. As an application, we give a description of theKasparov group $KK(\Dh, A\ot \Dh)$ in terms of $^*$-homomorphisms andasymptotic unitary equivalence. Along the way, we show that the Kasparov group$KK(\Dh, A\ot \Dh)$ is isomorphic to $K_0(A\ot \Dh)$.

direct_prompt: Proper motions of red clump giants in the Galactic bulge are important for understanding the dynamics of the Milky Way. In this study, we investigate the proper motion dispersions of red clump giants in the Galactic bulge using observations from the Gaia mission. We compare our observations to models of the Galactic bulge to gain insight into its structure and formation history. Our analysis reveals a clear trend of increasing proper motion dispersion with galactic latitude, indicating a complex and structured bulge. The observed proper motion dispersions are consistent with models that include a bar component and spiral arms. However, discrepancies between observations and models suggest that our current understanding of the Galactic bulge may be incomplete. Future observations and improved models will be crucial for refining our understanding of the dynamics of the Galactic bulge.

The proper motiondispersions are measured to a few per cent accuracy due to the large number ofstars in the fields. The observational sample is comprised of 577736 stars.These observed data are compared to a state-of-the-art particle simulation ofthe Galactic bulge region. The predictions are in rough agreement withobservations, but appear to be too anisotropic in the velocity ellipsoid. Wenote that there is significant field-to-field variation in the observed propermotion dispersions.

direct_prompt: Parity doubling in particle physics refers to the phenomenon where certain particles exhibit degenerate states under a parity transformation. This symmetry-breaking behavior has been of interest to researchers for decades, as it provides insight into the fundamental principles governing the universe. The concept of parity doubling has been observed in a variety of contexts, including in the study of mesons and baryons. By understanding the origins of parity doubling, scientists are able to better grasp the underlying symmetries and dynamics of particle interactions. Recent experimental evidence has further supported the existence of parity doubling in particle physics, leading to new discoveries and theoretical advancements in the field. The implications of parity doubling extend beyond theoretical physics, with potential applications in technologies such as quantum computing and high-energy particle accelerators.
human_text: Parity doubling in excited hadrons is reviewed. Parity degeneracy in hadronswas first experimentally observed 40 years ago. Recently new experimental dataon light mesons caused much excitement and renewed interest to the phenomenon,which still remains to be enigmatic. The present retrospective review is anattempt to trace the history of parity doubling phenomenon, thus providing akind of introduction to the subject. We begin with early approaches of 1960s(Regge theory and dynamical symmetries) and end up with the latest trends(manifestations of broader degeneracies and AdS/QCD). We show the evolution ofvarious ideas about parity doubling. The experimental evidence for thisphenomenon is scrutinized in the non-strange sector. Some experiments of 1960sdevoted to the search for missing non-strange bosons are re-examined and it isargued that results of these experiments are encouraging from the modernperspective.

direct_prompt: In this study, we present a systematic scan for 7-colourings of the grid, which is a layout commonly used in various combinatorial and computational problems. The grid is a discrete structure composed of interconnected points arranged in rows and columns, providing a convenient platform for studying colouring problems. Our method involves iteratively assigning colours to each point on the grid while enforcing the constraint that no adjacent points can have the same colour. Through extensive computational simulations, we explore the combinatorial possibilities of 7-colourings on grids of varying sizes. Our results reveal the existence of unique patterns and structures that emerge from the interplay between colouring constraints and grid topology. Furthermore, we discuss the implications of our findings on related fields such as graph theory and computational complexity.
human_text: We study the mixing time of a systematic scan Markov chain for sampling fromthe uniform distribution on proper 7-colourings of a finite rectangularsub-grid of the infinite square lattice, the grid. A systematic scan Markovchain cycles through finite-size subsets of vertices in a deterministic orderand updates the colours assigned to the vertices of each subset. The systematicscan Markov chain that we present cycles through subsets consisting of 2x2sub-grids and updates the colours assigned to the vertices using a procedureknown as heat-bath. We give a computer-assisted proof that this systematic scanMarkov chain mixes in O(log n) scans, where n is the size of the rectangularsub-grid. We make use of a heuristic to compute required couplings ofcolourings of 2x2 sub-grids.

direct_prompt: In this study, we investigate the behavior of continuous interfaces with disorder in two dimensions. Specifically, we examine the effects of pinning on the interface dynamics and how it interacts with disorder. Our results suggest that even strong pinning is not sufficient to completely stabilize the interface in two dimensions. The presence of disorder, particularly in the form of random pinning centers, leads to a complex interplay between pinning forces and thermal fluctuations. We find that the interface remains highly dynamic with a significant degree of roughness, even in the presence of strong pinning. Additionally, we observe that the system exhibits a range of different scaling behaviors depending on the strength of the pinning forces. Our findings highlight the challenges in controlling and stabilizing continuous interfaces in two dimensions, even with strong pinning mechanisms.

We show that an arbitarily weak random field term is enough tobeat an arbitrarily strong delta-pinning in 2 dimensions and will causedelocalization. direct_prompt: Epitaxial self-assembly is a promising technique for creating quantum dot arrays with defined structures. The order of quantum dots in these arrays plays a crucial role in their electronic and optical properties. By using linear analysis, the researchers were able to study the factors influencing the order of quantum dots and predict their spatial distribution. The results of this study provide valuable insights into controlling the order of quantum dots for various applications in optoelectronics and quantum information processing. Additionally, the findings contribute to the fundamental understanding of self-assembled nanostructures. The methodology and results presented in this article can be utilized to optimize the fabrication processes of quantum dot arrays. Future research could further explore the potential of linear analysis in predicting and controlling the order of quantum dots in epitaxial self-assembly.
human_text: Epitaxial self-assembled quantum dots (SAQDs) are of interest fornanostructured optoelectronic and electronic devices such as lasers,photodetectors and nanoscale logic. Spatial order and size order of SAQDs areimportant to the development of usable devices. It is likely that these twotypes of order are strongly linked; thus, a study of spatial order will alsohave strong implications for size order. Here a study of spatial order isundertaken using a linear analysis of a commonly used model of SAQD formationbased on surface diffusion. Analytic formulas for film-height correlationfunctions are found that characterize quantum dot spatial order andcorresponding correlation lengths that quantify order. Initial atomic-scalerandom fluctuations result in relatively small correlation lengths (about twodots) when the effect of a wetting potential is negligible; however, thecorrelation lengths diverge when SAQDs are allowed to form at a near-criticalfilm height.

direct_prompt: In this study, we present a new search for planet transits in the open star cluster NGC 6791. direct_prompt: In this study, we investigated the robustness of cortical networks against lesions through computational simulations. Using a state-of-the-art neural network model, we systematically induced lesions in different regions of the network to evaluate their impact on network functionality. Our results demonstrate that cortical networks exhibit a remarkable level of robustness against localized lesions, with only minor disruptions to network connectivity and information processing. Interestingly, we found that the degree of robustness varied depending on the location and size of the lesion, with certain regions being more critical for maintaining network integrity. Additionally, we observed that the network's ability to reorganize and compensate for lesions played a crucial role in preserving overall functionality. Furthermore, our simulations suggest that specific network properties, such as redundancy and modularity, contribute to the network's robustness against lesions.
human_text: Structural properties of networksrecently described allow their characterization as small-world, random(exponential) and scale-free. They complement the set of other properties thathave been explored in the context of brain connectivity, such as topology,hodology, clustering, and hierarchical organization. Here we apply new networkanalysis methods to cortical inter-areal connectivity networks for the cat andmacaque brains. We compare these corticocortical fibre networks to benchmarkrewired, small-world, scale-free and random networks, using two analysisstrategies, in which we measure the effects of the removal of nodes andconnections on the structural properties of the cortical networks. The brainnetworks' structural decay is in most respects similar to that of scale-freenetworks. The results implicate highly connected hub-nodes and bottleneckconnections as structural basis for some of the conditional robustness of brainsystems. This informs the understanding of the development of brain networks'connectivity.

direct_prompt: Our analysis utilized data collected from various telescopes and detectors to track the changing energy distribution of the burst over time. We found that the spectral properties of GRB 061121 evolved significantly from the prompt phase to the afterglow phase. The prompt phase showed a high-energy spectral component, indicative of the initial burst of gamma rays. As the burst transitioned into the afterglow phase, the spectrum shifted towards lower energies, consistent with the emission from the expanding shock front. Our observations suggest that the spectral evolution of GRB 061121 is complex and may be influenced by factors such as the surrounding environment and the magnetic field strength. The detailed analysis presented in this study provides valuable insights into the physics of gamma-ray bursts and their emission mechanisms.
human_text: Spectral evolution was seen throughout the burst, with the promptemission showing a clear positive correlation between brightness and hardness.The Spectral Energy Distribution (SED) of the prompt emission, stretching from1eV up to 1MeV, is very flat, with a peak in the flux density at ~1keV. Theoptical-to-X-ray spectra at this time are better fitted by a broken, ratherthan single, power-law, similar to previous results for X-ray flares. The SEDshows spectral hardening as the afterglow evolves with time. This behaviourmight be a symptom of self-Comptonisation, although circumstellar densitiessimilar to those found in the cores of molecular clouds would be required. Theafterglow also decays too slowly to be accounted for by the standard models.Although the precursor and main emission show different spectral lags, both areconsistent with the lag-luminosity correlation for long bursts.

direct_prompt: However, one major hurdle in realizing this potential is the phenomenon of decoherence, which can disrupt the delicate quantum states required for enhanced accuracy. In this article, we explore the various factors that contribute to decoherence in quantum-enhanced timing systems, including environmental noise and imperfections in experimental setups. We also discuss strategies for mitigating decoherence, such as error correction techniques and robust control methods. Additionally, we investigate the impact of decoherence on the overall timing accuracy achievable with quantum-enhanced systems. Our analysis reveals the complex interplay between decoherence and timing accuracy, highlighting the need for further research in this area. Ultimately, a better understanding of decoherence in quantum-enhanced timing systems will be crucial for realizing their full potential in precision timekeeping applications.
human_text: Quantum enhancement of optical pulse timing accuracy is investigated in theHeisenberg picture. Effects of optical loss, group-velocity dispersion, andKerr nonlinearity on the position and momentum of an optical pulse are studiedvia Heisenberg equations of motion. Using the developed formalism, the impactof decoherence by optical loss on the use of adiabatic soliton control forbeating the timing standard quantum limit [Tsang, Phys. Rev. Lett. 97, 023902(2006)] is analyzed theoretically and numerically. The analysis shows that anappreciable enhancement can be achieved using current technology, despite anincrease in timing jitter mainly due to the Gordon-Haus effect. The decoherenceeffect of optical loss on the transmission of quantum-enhanced timinginformation is also studied, in order to identify situations in which theenhancement is able to survive.

human_text: In binaries with eccentric orbits, periodic perturbation of theouter disk is predicted to induce mass flow across the gap, resulting inaccretion that varies with the binary period. This accretion may manifestitself observationally as periodic changes in luminosity. Here we present asearch for such periodic accretion in the pre-main-sequence spectroscopicbinary UZ Tau E. We present BVRI photometry spanning three years; we find thatthe brightness of UZ Tau E is clearly periodic, with a best-fit period of 19.16+/- 0.04 days. This is consistent with the spectroscopic binary period of 19.13days, refined here from analysis of new and existing radial velocity data. Thebrightness of UZ Tau E shows significant random variability, but the overallperiodic pattern is a broad peak in enhanced brightness, spanning more thanhalf the binary orbital period.

direct_prompt: In this study, we investigate the behavior of a Wigner crystal confined within a one-dimensional quantum dot using numerical simulations. Our results show that as the strength of the electron-electron interaction increases, the Wigner crystal deforms, exhibiting a nonuniform density distribution along the quantum dot. Through a series of calculations, we determine the critical interaction strength at which the Wigner crystal transitions from a uniform to a deformed state. Additionally, we analyze the effects of varying electron density and confinement potential on the deformation of the Wigner crystal. Our findings suggest that the shape and stability of the Wigner crystal within a one-dimensional quantum dot can be tailored by controlling these parameters. These results have implications for understanding the behavior of electrons in nanostructures and could inform the design of electronic devices with tailored properties.
human_text: The spatial Fourier spectrum of the electron density distribution in a finite1D system and the distribution function of electrons over single-particlestates are studied in detail to show that there are two universal features intheir behavior, which characterize the electron ordering and the deformation ofWigner crystal by boundaries. The distribution function has a $\delta$-likesingularity at the Fermi momentum $k_F$. The Fourier spectrum of the densityhas a step-like form at the wavevector $2k_F$, with the harmonics being absentor vanishing above this threshold. These features are found by calculationsusing exact diagonalization method. They are shown to be caused by Wignerordering of electrons, affected by the boundaries. However the common Luttingerliquid model with open boundaries fails to capture these features, because itoverestimates the deformation of the Wigner crystal.

direct_prompt: The prompt emission phase of GRBs, occurring within the first several seconds of the burst, is characterized by the production of high energy photons. These photons, with energies ranging from keV to GeV, provide crucial insights into the physics of GRBs and the processes involved in their formation. Understanding the prompt emission of high energy photons is essential for unraveling the complex mechanisms at play in these cataclysmic events. In this article, we review the current state of knowledge regarding the prompt emission of high energy photons from GRBs, including the observed characteristics and theoretical models proposed to explain them. We discuss the role of processes such as synchrotron radiation, inverse Compton scattering, and photospheric emission in shaping the observed spectra and temporal profiles of high energy photons in GRBs.
human_text: Our results suggest that the highenergy emission is dominated by the leptonic component if fraction of shockenergy carried by electrons is not very small (e.g. $\epsilon_e > 10^{-3}$).For very small values of $\epsilon_e$ the hadronic emission component could becomparable to or even exceed the leptonic component in the GeV-TeV regime.However, in this case a much larger energy budget of the fireball is requiredto account for the same level of the observed sub-MeV spectrum. The fireballsare therefore extremely inefficient in radiation. For a canonical fireball bulkLorentz factor (e.g. $\Gamma=400$), emissions above $\sim 10$ GeV areattenuated by two-photon pair production processes. For a fireball with an evenhigher Lorentz factor, the cutoff energy is higher, and emissions of 10 TeV -PeV due to $\pi^0$-decay can also escape from the internal shocks.

direct_prompt: This article explores the concept of an inverse $f(R)$ gravitation model as a potential explanation for the cosmic acceleration observed in the universe. By introducing a modified gravitational theory, the need for dark energy to explain the observed acceleration can be potentially eliminated. The implications of this alternative model for both theoretical cosmology and observational cosmology are discussed. Additionally, the potential observational signatures that could distinguish this inverse $f(R)$ gravitation model from other dark energy models are considered.
human_text: To explain the cosmic speed up, brought to light by the recent SNIa and CMBobservations, we propose the following: a) In a spacetime endowed with a FRWmetric, we choose an empirical scale factor that best explains theobservations. b) We assume a modified gravity, generated by an unspecifiedfield lagrangian, $f(R)$. c) We use the adopted empirical scale factor to workback retroactively to obtain $f(R)$, hence the term `Inverse $f(R)$'. d) Nextwe consider the classic GR and a conventional FRW universe that, in addition toits known baryonic content, possesses a hypothetical `Dark Energy' component.We compare the two scenarios, and find the density, the pressure, and theequation of the state of the Dark Energy required to make up for thedifferences between the conventional and the modified GR models.

direct_prompt: In this paper, we introduce a general nonlinear Fokker-Planck equation that encompasses a wide range of physical systems exhibiting nonlinear dynamics. We study the associated entropy of this equation and derive a variational principle that governs its evolution. Through numerical simulations, we demonstrate the behavior of the system under various initial conditions and parameter values. Our results show that the entropy of the system increases over time, in accordance with the second law of thermodynamics. Overall, our findings provide new insights into the dynamics of nonlinear systems and the role of entropy in governing their evolution.
human_text: A recently introduced nonlinear Fokker-Planck equation, derived directly froma master equation, comes out as a very general tool to describephenomenologically systems presenting complex behavior, like anomalousdiffusion, in the presence of external forces. Such an equation ischaracterized by a nonlinear diffusion term that may present, in general, twodistinct powers of the probability distribution. Herein, we calculate thestationary-state distributions of this equation in some special cases, andintroduce associated classes of generalized entropies in order to satisfy theH-theorem. Within this approach, the parameters associated with the transitionrates of the original master-equation are related to such generalizedentropies, and are shown to obey some restrictions. Some particular cases arediscussed.
