direct_prompt: In this study, we investigate the high energy evolution equation by incorporating running coupling corrections. We introduce a new framework that accounts for the running of the coupling constant with energy scale. This is crucial for accurately describing the evolution of parton distributions at high energies. Our analysis focuses on understanding how running coupling corrections affect the evolution equation and its solutions. We find that including running coupling corrections leads to significant changes in the evolution behavior of parton distributions. Our results provide important insights into the high energy behavior of parton distributions and have implications for understanding particle interactions at high energies. Overall, our study contributes to the ongoing efforts to improve the theoretical understanding of QCD phenomena at high energies.
human_text: Therunning coupling corrections calculated recently significantly change the shapeof the scaling function as compared to the fixed coupling case leading to aconsiderable increase in the anomalous dimension and to a slow-down of theevolution with rapidity. The difference between the two recent calculations isdue to an extra contribution to the evolution kernel, referred to as thesubtraction term, which arises when running coupling corrections are included.These subtraction terms were neglected in both recent calculations. We evaluatenumerically the subtraction terms for both calculations, and demonstrate thatwhen the subtraction terms are added back to the evolution kernels obtained inthe two works the resulting dipole amplitudes agree with each other! We thenuse the complete running coupling kernel including the subtraction term to findthe numerical solution of the resulting full non-linear evolution equation withthe running coupling corrections.

direct_prompt: This study explores the behavior of circular and non-circular nearly horizon-skimming orbits in Kerr spacetimes. Kerr spacetimes are characterized by their rotating black holes, which introduce complex gravitational effects on test particles orbiting them. Circular orbits are those in which a particle maintains a fixed distance from the black hole, while non-circular orbits exhibit varying distances. The nearly horizon-skimming nature of these orbits refers to their proximity to the event horizon of the black hole. The dynamics of such orbits are of interest due to their potential impact on the accretion processes that occur around black holes. In this paper, we analyze the properties of these orbits and their stability in Kerr spacetimes. We find that circular orbits are more stable near the event horizon compared to non-circular orbits.
human_text: Such behavior was notedpreviously for circular orbits; since it only applies to orbits very close tothe black hole, they were named "nearly horizon-skimming orbits". Our analysisgeneralizes this result, mapping out the full generic (inclined and eccentric)family of nearly horizon-skimming orbits. The earlier work on circular orbitsreported that, under gravitational radiation emission, nearly horizon-skimmingorbits tend to evolve to smaller orbit inclination, toward prograde equatorialconfiguration. Normal orbits, by contrast, always demonstrate slowly growingorbit inclination (orbits evolve toward the retrograde equatorialconfiguration). Using up-to-date Teukolsky-fluxes, we have concluded that theearlier result was incorrect: all circular orbits, including nearlyhorizon-skimming ones, exhibit growing orbit inclination. Using kludge fluxesbased on a Post-Newtonian expansion corrected with fits to circular and toequatorial Teukolsky-fluxes, we argue that the inclination grows also foreccentric nearly horizon-skimming orbits.

direct_prompt: The repository is designed to be user-friendly and easily searchable. Users can access and download the light curves for their own analysis and research purposes. The online repository facilitates data sharing and collaboration among researchers studying GRBs. It enables scientists to compare and contrast light curves from different GRBs and derive meaningful conclusions. The repository also includes tools for data visualization and analysis, enhancing the research capabilities of users. By providing a centralized location for Swift/XRT light curves of GRBs, the repository aims to promote and facilitate research in this field. Researchers can contribute their own light curves to the repository, further expanding its database. Overall, the online repository serves as a valuable resource for the GRB research community, offering a wealth of data and tools for analysis.
human_text: Context. Swift data are revolutionising our understanding of Gamma RayBursts. Since bursts fade rapidly, it is desirable to create and disseminateaccurate light curves rapidly. Aims. To provide the community with an online repository of X-ray lightcurves obtained with Swift. The light curves should be of the quality expectedof published data, but automatically created and updated so as to beself-consistent and rapidly available. Methods. We have produced a suite ofprograms which automatically generates Swift/XRT light curves of GRBs. Effectsof the damage to the CCD, automatic readout-mode switching and pile-up areappropriately handled, and the data are binned with variable bin durations, asnecessary for a fading source. Results. The light curve repository website(http://www.swift.ac.uk/xrt_curves) contains light curves, hardness ratios anddeep images for every GRB which Swift's XRT has observed.

direct_prompt: Utilizing theoretical calculations and simulations, the evolution of the electronic structure in the presence of varying temperatures is explored. The Wigner Crystal phase, characterized by long-range Coulomb interactions dominating the electron behavior, gradually transforms into the Bond-Charge-Density Wave phase as the temperature increases. The relationship between temperature and electron localization is thoroughly analyzed, shedding light on the intricate transition mechanisms between different ordered states. The influence of thermal fluctuations on the electronic properties is examined, providing insights into the dynamic behavior of the system. Quantum fluctuations play a significant role in driving the transition from the Wigner Crystal to the Bond-Charge-Density Wave phase. The emergence of novel physical phenomena at elevated temperatures is discussed, highlighting the importance of temperature in controlling the electronic properties of quasi-one-dimensional systems.
human_text: It is known that within the interacting electron model Hamiltonian for theone-dimensional 1/4-filled band, the singlet ground state is a Wigner crystalonly if the nearest neighbor electron-electron repulsion is larger than acritical value. We show that this critical nearest neighbor Coulomb interactionis different for each spin subspace, with the critical value decreasing withincreasing spin. As a consequence, with the lowering of temperature, there canoccur a transition from a Wigner crystal charge-ordered state to a spin-Peierlsstate that is a Bond-Charge-Density Wave with charge occupancies different fromthe Wigner crystal. This transition is possible because spin excitations fromthe spin-Peierls state in the 1/4-filled band are necessarily accompanied bychanges in site charge densities. We apply our theory to the 1/4-filled bandquasi-one-dimensional organic charge-transfer solids in general and to 2:1tetramethyltetrathiafulvalene (TMTTF) and tetramethyltetraselenafulvalene(TMTSF) cationic salts in particular.

direct_prompt: The IDV source J1128+5925 is a newly discovered astronomical object that shows potential for exhibiting annual modulation. This candidate for annual modulation was identified through intensive observational data analysis of its light curves. The object's variability is consistent with an annual pattern, suggesting a possible modulation effect. The source's position in the sky and its characteristics make it a promising target for further study in order to confirm its annual modulation behavior. The candidate's unique properties set it apart from other IDV sources and make it an intriguing subject for research. This discovery opens up new avenues for studying the phenomenon of annual modulation in astronomical objects. The potential for annual modulation in J1128+5925 could have significant implications for our understanding of rapid variability in celestial objects.
human_text: We measure the characteristic variability time-scale of the IDVthroughout the year, and analyze whether the observed changes in thevariability time-scale are consistent with annual modulation. We monitored theflux density variability of J1128+5925 with dense time sampling between 2.7 and10.45GHz with the 100m Effelsberg radio telescope of the MPIfR and with the 25mUrumqi radio telescope. From ten observing sessions, we determine thevariability characteristics and time-scales. The observed pronounced changes ofthe variability time-scale of J1128+5925 are modelled with an anisotropicannual modulation model. The observed frequency dependence of the variation isin good agreement with the prediction from interstellar scintillation. Adoptinga simple model for the annual modulation model and using also the frequencydependence of the IDV, we derive a lower limit to the distance of thescattering screen and an upper limit to the scintillating source size.

The presence of radio emission from the IMBH in G1 provides valuable insights into the accretion processes and environment of intermediate-mass black holes in dense stellar systems. Further observations and theoretical modeling are necessary to fully understand the nature of the radio emission and its implications for the evolution of IMBHs in globular clusters.

A pulsar wind nebula is also a possiblecandidate for the radio and X-ray emission from G1; future high-sensitivityVLBI observations might distinguish between this possibility and an IMBH. direct_prompt: In this article, we investigate the total photo-absorption cross section of $^4$He using chiral effective field theory including two- and three-nucleon interactions. We utilize a theoretical framework that incorporates the dynamics of nucleons and pions to accurately describe the nuclear interactions. Our calculations are based on the leading order chiral effective field theory and include the effects of two- and three-nucleon forces. We compare our theoretical predictions with experimental data from previous studies to validate the accuracy of our model. Our results demonstrate that including three-nucleon interactions in addition to two-nucleon interactions improves the agreement with experimental observations. Overall, our study provides a comprehensive understanding of the total photo-absorption cross section of $^4$He and highlights the importance of three-nucleon interactions in accurately describing nuclear processes.
human_text: The total photo-absorption cross section of $^4$He is evaluatedmicroscopically using two- (NN) and three-nucleon (NNN) interactions based uponchiral effective field theory ($\chi$EFT). The calculation is performed usingthe Lorentz integral transform method along with the {\em ab initio} no-coreshell model approach. An important feature of the present study is theconsistency of the NN and NNN interactions and also, through the Siegerttheorem, of the two- and three-body current operators. This is due to theapplication of the $\chi$EFT framework. The inclusion of the NNN interactionproduces a suppression of the low-energy peak and enhancement of thehigh-energy tail of the cross section. We compare to calculations obtainedusing other interactions and to representative experiments. The rather confusedexperimental situation in the giant resonance region prevents discriminationamong different interaction models.

direct_prompt: The model incorporates key physical processes such as star formation, chemical enrichment, and feedback from supernovae to provide a comprehensive understanding of galaxy evolution. The SPITZER data provides observational constraints on the properties of galaxies in the infra-red, allowing for a comparison with the model predictions. Our results show good agreement between the model and the SPITZER data for various galaxy properties, including star formation rates, stellar masses, and metallicities. By comparing the model with observational data, we gain insights into the physical processes driving galaxy evolution in the infra-red. This research contributes to a better understanding of the formation and evolution of galaxies across cosmic time and highlights the importance of incorporating infra-red observations into galaxy formation models.
human_text: We present predictions for the evolution of the galaxy luminosity function,number counts and redshift distributions in the IR based on the Lambda-CDMcosmological model. We use the combined GALFORM semi-analytical galaxyformation model and GRASIL spectrophotometric code to compute galaxy SEDsincluding the reprocessing of radiation by dust. The model, which is the sameas that in Baugh et al (2005), assumes two different IMFs: a normal solarneighbourhood IMF for quiescent star formation in disks, and a very top-heavyIMF in starbursts triggered by galaxy mergers. We have shown previously thatthe top-heavy IMF seems to be necessary to explain the number counts of faintsub-mm galaxies. We compare the model with observational data from the SPITZERSpace Telescope, with the model parameters fixed at values chosen beforeSPITZER data became available.

direct_prompt: In this study, we investigate the spin solid phases of spin 1 and spin 3/2 antiferromagnets on a cubic lattice. We use a combination of mean-field theory and numerical simulations to analyze the ground state properties of these systems. Our results reveal the presence of rich magnetic phase diagrams with various spin arrangements in both spin 1 and spin 3/2 antiferromagnets. We observe the emergence of spin solid phases with different ordering patterns, including collinear and non-collinear arrangements. Additionally, we find that the spin solid phases exhibit distinct magnetic properties, such as spin correlations and magnetic entanglement. Our findings shed light on the intricate behavior of spin solid phases in antiferromagnetic systems on a cubic lattice, providing valuable insights for future research in spintronics and quantum magnetism.
human_text: We study spin S=1 and S=3/2 Heisenberg antiferromagnets on a cubic latticefocusing on spin solid states. Using Schwinger boson formulation for spins, westart in a U(1) spin liquid phase proximate to Neel phase and explore possibleconfining paramagnetic phases as we transition away from the spin liquid by theprocess of monopole condensation. Electromagnetic duality is used to rewritethe theory in terms of monopoles. For spin 1 we find several candidate phasesof which the most natural one is a phase with spins organized into parallelHaldane chains. For spin 3/2 we find that the most natural phase has spinsorganized into parallel ladders. As a by-product, we also write a Landau theoryof the ordering in two special classical frustrated XY models on the cubiclattice, one of which is the fully frustrated XY model.

direct_prompt: This article presents research on the effects of doping rich methane premixed laminar flames with light unsaturated hydrocarbons, specifically allene and propyne. Through experimental and numerical simulations, the flame structures and emissions of these doped flames were analyzed and compared to the undoped methane flames. The addition of allene and propyne resulted in significant changes in the flame properties, including flame temperature, NOx emissions, and soot formation. The presence of allene and propyne was found to enhance soot formation while reducing NOx emissions in the doped flames. Additionally, the impact of doping with these light unsaturated hydrocarbons on flame stability and overall combustion characteristics was studied. Overall, this research provides valuable insights into the combustion behavior of rich methane flames doped with allene and propyne, with implications for improved understanding of pollutant formation mechanisms in combustion processes.
human_text: The structure of three laminar premixed rich flames has been investigated: apure methane flame and two methane flames doped by allene and propyne,respectively. The gases of the three flames contain 20.9% (molar) of methaneand 33.4% of oxygen, corresponding to an equivalence ratio of 1.25 for the puremethane flame. In both doped flames, 2.49% of C3H4 was added, corresponding toa ratio C3H4/CH4 of 12% and an equivalence ratio of 1.55. The three flames havebeen stabilized on a burner at a pressure of 6.7 kPa using argon as dilutant,with a gas velocity at the burner of 36 cm/s at 333 K. The concentrationprofiles of stable species were measured by gas chromatography after samplingwith a quartz microprobe. Quantified species included carbon monoxide anddioxide, methane, oxygen, hydrogen, ethane, ethylene, acetylene, propyne,allene, propene, propane, 1,2-butadiene, 1,3-butadiene, 1-butene, isobutene,1-butyne, vinylacetylene, and benzene.

direct_prompt: In this study, we explore how certain key properties of string theory, such as extra dimensions and supersymmetry, can manifest in the observed CMB signal. We use state-of-the-art statistical methods to analyze the latest CMB data from the Planck satellite, looking for signatures of string theory effects. Our results show that certain aspects of string theory can indeed leave a distinctive imprint on the CMB power spectrum, providing a unique opportunity to test this fundamental theory of physics. By comparing our theoretical predictions with observational data, we can constrain parameters of string theory and potentially rule out certain theoretical frameworks. This work opens up a new avenue for testing and validating string theory using cosmological observations, offering insights into the ultimate nature of the universe.
human_text: Future detection/non-detection of tensor modes from inflation in CMBobservations presents a unique way to test certain features of string theory.Current limit on the ratio of tensor to scalar perturbations, r=T/S, is r <0.3, future detection may take place for r > 10^{-2}-10^{-3}. At present allknown string theory inflation models predict tensor modes well below the levelof detection. Therefore a possible experimental discovery of tensor modes maypresent a challenge to string cosmology. The strongest bound on r in string inflation follows from the observationthat in most of the models based on the KKLT construction, the value of theHubble constant H during inflation must be smaller than the gravitino mass. Forthe gravitino mass in the usual range, m_{3/2} < O(1) TeV, this leads to anextremely strong bound r < 10^{-24}.

direct_prompt: Gravitational waves are ripples in spacetime that are generated when massive objects accelerate. In this study, we investigate the effect of self-gravity on the propagation of gravitational-wave packets. We find that the self-gravity of the gravitational-wave packets causes a distortion in their shape as they travel through spacetime. This distortion can impact the accuracy of measurements taken by detectors, such as interferometers. Our analysis reveals that the extent of the distortion is dependent on the amplitude and frequency of the gravitational waves. Overall, understanding the impact of self-gravity on gravitational-wave packets is crucial for accurately detecting and interpreting these elusive signals from distant cosmic events.
human_text: The GW pulse is distorted by the gravitational effect of theself-energy residing in between these shells. We illustrate this distortion forGW pulses from the final plunge of black hole (BH) binaries, leading to theevolution of the GW profile as a function of the radial distance from thesource. The distortion depends on the total GW energy released and the durationof the emission, scaled by the total binary mass, M. The effect should berelevant in finite box simulations where the waveforms are extracted within aradius of <~ 100M. For characteristic emission parameters at the final plungebetween binary BHs of arbitrary spins, this effect could distort the simulatedGW templates for LIGO and LISA by a fraction of 0.001. Accounting for the wavedistortion would significantly decrease the waveform extraction errors innumerical simulations.

direct_prompt: Key challenges and opportunities in radio astrometric detection are discussed, including the need for improved sensitivity and resolution in radio telescopes. The paper also highlights the importance of collaborations between radio astronomers and exoplanet researchers to further advance the field. By harnessing the power of radio astrometry, researchers have the potential to discover new exoplanets, study their atmospheres, and explore their orbits in greater detail. The paper discusses the technological advancements needed to achieve these goals, including the development of next-generation radio telescopes with higher precision and sensitivity. Additionally, the paper addresses the potential impact of radio astrometric detection on our understanding of planet formation and evolution. The authors propose a series of recommendations for the NSF ExoPlanet Task Force to support and promote research in radio astrometry.
human_text: Currently, the Very Long Baseline Array can routinely achievebetter than 100 microarcsecond accuracy, and can approach 10 microarcsecondwith careful calibration. We describe here RIPL, the Radio InterferometricPLanet search, a new program with the VLBA and the Green Bank 100 m telescopethat will survey 29 low-mass, active stars over 3 years with sub-Jovian planetmass sensitivity at 1 AU. An upgrade of the VLBA bandwidth will increaseastrometric accuracy by an order of magnitude. Ultimately, the colossalcollecting area of the Square Kilometer Array could push astrometric accuracyto 1 microarcsecond, making detection and characterizaiton of Earth massplanets possible. RIPL and other future radio astrometric planet searches occupy a uniquevolume in planet discovery and characterization parameter space. The parameterspace of astrometric searches gives greater sensitivity to planets at largeradii than radial velocity searches.

direct_prompt: The self-interaction cross-section of dark matter remains a fundamental unknown in our understanding of the cosmological landscape. In this study, we investigate constraints on the self-interaction cross-section of dark matter by analyzing numerical simulations of the merging galaxy cluster 1E 0657-5. By comparing the observed properties of the galaxy cluster with simulated models incorporating different values of the self-interaction cross-section, we are able to place limits on this crucial parameter. Our results show that a non-zero, but still relatively small, self-interaction cross-section is favored by the data. We find that larger values of the self-interaction cross-section are disfavored due to inconsistencies with the observed dynamics of the merging galaxy cluster. These constraints provide valuable insight into the nature of dark matter and its interactions with ordinary matter on astrophysical scales.

Previous studies,based on older observational datasets, have placed upper limits on theself-interaction cross-section of dark matter per unit mass, sigma/m, usingsimplified analytic techniques. In this work, we take advantage of new,higher-quality observational datasets by running N-body simulations of1E0657-56 that include the effects of self-interacting dark matter, andcomparing the results with observations. Furthermore, the recent data allow fora new independent method of constraining sigma/m, based on the non-observationof an offset between the bullet subcluster mass peak and galaxy centroid. Thisnew method places an upper limit (68% confidence) of sigma/m < 1.25 cm^2/g.

direct_prompt: In this study, we investigate the phenomenon of a lower ground state in a trapped ion system caused by counter-rotating wave interaction. We demonstrate that the interplay between the rotating and counter-rotating waves leads to a decrease in the energy of the ground state of the system. Our theoretical analysis reveals the conditions under which this lower ground state can be achieved, and we provide numerical simulations to support our findings. Additionally, we discuss the implications of this phenomenon for quantum information processing and quantum computing applications. Our results suggest that the manipulation of counter-rotating wave interactions could provide a new avenue for controlling the dynamics of trapped ion systems and enhancing their coherence properties. This work contributes to the ongoing research in quantum technologies and advances our understanding of the fundamental physics underlying trapped ion systems.

In the strong-excitation regime and without the restriction ofLamb-Dicke limit, the Hamiltonian of the system is similar to a drivingJaynes-Cummings model without rotating wave approximation (RWA). The approachwe developed enables us to present a complete eigensolutions, which makes itavailable to compare with the solutions under the RWA. We find that, the groundstate in our non-RWA solution is energically lower than the counterpart underthe RWA. If we have the ion in the ground state, it is equivalent to a spindependent force on the trapped ion. direct_prompt: In this study, we investigated the size-dependent structure and strain of CdSe nanoparticles using atomic pair distribution function (PDF) analysis. The nanoparticles were prepared via a colloidal synthesis method and characterized using X-ray diffraction and transmission electron microscopy. By analyzing the PDF data obtained from X-ray diffraction measurements, we were able to determine the quantitative size distribution and average strain in the nanoparticles. Our results revealed a size-dependent evolution of the nanoparticle structure, with larger nanoparticles exhibiting a more pronounced strain effect. This study provides valuable insights into the structural properties of CdSe nanoparticles and demonstrates the utility of PDF analysis for studying size-dependent effects in nanomaterials. Overall, our findings contribute to the fundamental understanding of nanoparticle growth and structural evolution processes.
human_text: The size-dependent structure of CdSe nanoparticles, with diameters rangingfrom 2 to 4 nm, has been studied using the atomic pair distribution function(PDF) method. The core structure of the measured CdSe nanoparticles can bedescribed in terms of the wurtzite atomic structure with extensive stackingfaults. The density of faults in the nanoparticles ~50% . The diameter of thecore region was extracted directly from the PDF data and is in good agreementwith the diameter obtained from standard characterization methods suggestingthat there is little surface amorphous region. A compressive strain wasmeasured in the Cd-Se bond length that increases with decreasing particle sizebeing 0.5% with respect to bulk CdSe for the 2 nm diameter particles. Thisstudy demonstrates the size-dependent quantitative structural information thatcan be obtained even from very small nanoparticles using the PDF approach.

direct_prompt: In this study, we present a quantitative analysis of the Si(111)-3x2-Sm surface structure using LEED I-V measurements and ab initio calculations. Our results reveal a detailed understanding of the surface atomic arrangement and the presence of Sm on the Si substrate. Additionally, we investigate the origin of the missing half order spots in the 3x1 diffraction pattern of the surface, shedding light on possible structural defects or surface reconstructions. Overall, our combined experimental and theoretical approach provides valuable insights into the intriguing surface properties of the Si(111)-3x2-Sm system.
human_text: We have used Low Energy Electron Diffraction (LEED) I-V analysis and abinitio calculations to quantitatively determine the honeycomb chain modelstructure for the Si(111)-3x2-Sm surface. This structure and a similar 3x1recontruction have been observed for many Alkali-Earth and Rare-Earth metals onthe Si(111) surface. Our ab initio calculations show that there are two almostdegenerate sites for the Sm atom in the unit cell and the LEED I-V analysisreveals that an admixture of the two in a ratio that slightly favours the sitewith the lower energy is the best match to experiment. We show that the I-Vcurves are insensitive to the presence of the Sm atom and that this results ina very low intensity for the half order spots which might explain theappearance of a 3x1 LEED pattern produced by all of the structures with a 3x2unit cell.

direct_prompt: Fractional reaction-diffusion equations are important models in various fields of science and engineering due to their ability to describe complex transport phenomena. In this study, we focus on finding analytical solutions of fractional reaction-diffusion equations using the H-function method. The H-function has proven to be a powerful tool for solving various types of fractional differential equations. We demonstrate the effectiveness of the H-function method by considering several examples of fractional reaction-diffusion equations with different types of boundary conditions. The analytical solutions obtained using the H-function method provide insights into the behavior of the systems described by the fractional reaction-diffusion equations. Our results show that the H-function method can be a valuable tool for studying and analyzing fractional reaction-diffusion equations in a variety of applications.
human_text: This paper deals with the investigation of the solution of an unifiedfractional reaction-diffusion equation associated with the Caputo derivative asthe time-derivative and Riesz-Feller fractional derivative as thespace-derivative. The solution is derived by the application of the Laplace andFourier transforms in closed form in terms of the H-function. The resultsderived are of general nature and include the results investigated earlier bymany authors, notably by Mainardi et al. (2001, 2005) for the fundamentalsolution of the space-time fractional diffusion equation, and Saxena et al. (2006a, b) for fractional reaction- diffusion equations. The advantage of usingRiesz-Feller derivative lies in the fact that the solution of the fractionalreaction-diffusion equation containing this derivative includes the fundamentalsolution for space-time fractional diffusion, which itself is a generalizationof neutral fractional diffusion, space-fractional diffusion, andtime-fractional diffusion.

direct_prompt: This study explores the decomposition of functions on quadratic surfaces into multipole moments. The use of multipole moments allows for a more concise and efficient representation of these functions. By deconstructing functions into multipole moments, we are able to isolate specific features and behaviors of the original function. The methodology involves representing functions as a sum of multipole moments such as monopole, dipole, and quadrupole moments. These multipole moments capture the global and local aspects of the function on the quadratic surface. The decomposition process provides valuable insights into the underlying structure and symmetries of the functions. We demonstrate the effectiveness of this approach through numerical simulations and applications to real-world scenarios. The results show that multipole moments offer a powerful tool for analyzing and understanding functions on quadratic surfaces.

Over the complex numbers, the above representation is notunique, although the ambiguity is essentially finite. We investigate thecombinatorics that depicts this ambiguity. We link these results with someclassical theorems of harmonic analysis, theorems that describe decompositionsof functions into sums of spherical harmonics. We extend these classicaltheorems (which rely on our understanding of the Laplace operator$\Delta_{S^2}$) to more general differential operators $\Delta_Q$ that areconstructed with the help of the quadratic form $Q(x, y, z)$. Then we introducemodular spaces of multipoles. We study their intricate geometry and topologyusing methods of algebraic geometry and singularity theory.

direct_prompt: In this study, we investigate the upper bounds on the entangling rates of bipartite Hamiltonians. We introduce a novel methodology to quantify the maximum rates at which bipartite systems can generate entanglement. Our results demonstrate that certain classes of Hamiltonians have intrinsic limitations on their entangling capabilities. Additionally, we provide analytical expressions for the upper bounds on entangling rates for specific types of Hamiltonians. These findings have implications for the design and engineering of quantum systems for tasks requiring high rates of entanglement generation.
human_text: Given abipartite Hamiltonian H coupling two finite dimensional particles A and B, theentangling rate is shown to be upper bounded by c*log(d)*norm(H), where d isthe smallest dimension of the interacting particles, norm(H) is the operatornorm of H, and c is a constant close to 1. Under certain restrictions on theinitial state we prove analogous upper bound for the ancilla-assistedentangling rate with a constant c that does not depend upon dimensions of localancillas. The restriction is that the initial state has at most two distinctSchmidt coefficients (each coefficient may have arbitrarily largemultiplicity). Our proof is based on analysis of a mixing rate -- a functionalmeasuring how fast entropy can be produced if one mixes a time-independentstate with a state evolving unitarily.

direct_prompt: In this study, we explore the presence of symplectic symmetry in the ab initio no-core shell model calculations for light nuclei. We find strong evidence supporting the existence of symplectic symmetry, which plays a crucial role in describing nuclear structure. Our results indicate that the symplectic symmetry can accurately reproduce experimental data for light nuclei. This study highlights the importance of considering symplectic symmetry in nuclear structure calculations.
human_text: Clear evidence for symplectic symmetry in low-lying states of $^{12}$C and$^{16}$O is reported. Eigenstates of $^{12}$C and $^{16}$O, determined withinthe framework of the no-core shell model using the JISP16 $NN$ realisticinteraction, typically project at the 85-90% level onto a few of the mostdeformed symplectic basis states that span only a small fraction of the fullmodel space. The results are nearly independent of whether the bare orrenormalized effective interactions are used in the analysis. The outcomeconfirms Elliott's \SU{3} model which underpins the symplectic scheme, andabove all, points to the relevance of a symplectic no-core shell model that canreproduce experimental B(E2) values without effective charges as well asdeformed spatial modes associated with clustering phenomena in nuclei.

direct_prompt: This study explores the intramolecular long-range correlations present in polymer melts by analyzing the segmental size distribution and its moments. The statistical analysis reveals how polymer chains in melts exhibit non-random behavior and long-range correlations. The segmental size distribution and its moments provide insights into the spatial organization and dynamics of polymer chains in the melt state. Understanding these correlations is crucial for designing advanced materials with tailored properties.
human_text: Presenting theoretical arguments and numerical results we demonstratelong-range intrachain correlations in concentrated solutions and melts of longflexible polymers which cause a systematic swelling of short chain segments.They can be traced back to the incompressibility of the melt leading to aneffective repulsion $u(s) \approx s/\rho R^3(s) \approx ce/\sqrt{s}$ whenconnecting two segments together where $s$ denotes the curvilinear length of asegment, $R(s)$ its typical size, $ce \approx 1/\rho be^3$ the ``swellingcoefficient", $be$ the effective bond length and $\rho$ the monomer density.The relative deviation of the segmental size distribution from the idealGaussian chain behavior is found to be proportional to $u(s)$. The analysis ofdifferent moments of this distribution allows for a precise determination ofthe effective bond length $be$ and the swelling coefficient $ce$ ofasymptotically long chains.

direct_prompt: The Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) is a powerful tool for studying the solar chromosphere due to its high spatial resolution and sensitivity to millimeter and submillimeter wavelengths. This article explores the unique capabilities of ALMA in observing the temperature and density structure of the solar chromosphere, providing valuable insights into its dynamic and complex nature. By observing molecular lines and continuum emission, ALMA can help to improve our understanding of the processes driving heating and mass transport in the chromosphere. Additionally, ALMA's ability to observe multiple spectral lines simultaneously allows for detailed studies of the physical conditions and magnetic fields within the chromosphere. Overall, ALMA represents an ideal probe for investigating the solar chromosphere and advancing our knowledge of this crucial region of the solar atmosphere.
human_text: Computations carried outwith a sophisticated dynamic model of the solar chromosphere due to Carlssonand Stein demonstrate that millimeter emission is extremely sensitive todynamic processes in the chromosphere and the appropriate wavelengths to lookfor dynamic signatures are in the range 0.8-5.0 mm. The model also suggeststhat high resolution observations at mm wavelengths, as will be provided byALMA, will have the unique property of reacting to both the hot and the coolgas, and thus will have the potential of distinguishing between rival models ofthe solar atmosphere. Thus, initial results obtained from the observations ofthe quiet Sun at 3.5 mm with the BIMA array (resolution of 12 arcsec) revealsignificant oscillations with amplitudes of 50-150 K and frequencies of 1.5-8mHz with a tendency toward short-period oscillations in internetwork and longerperiods in network regions.

direct_prompt: In this study, we explore the concept of flavour-dependent Type II leptogenesis, a mechanism that can explain the matter-antimatter asymmetry in the universe. We examine how the inclusion of flavour effects in the leptonic Yukawa couplings can lead to different lepton asymmetries for the different lepton flavours. Using a simplified model, we calculate the lepton asymmetry generated in the early universe and investigate how it depends on the flavour structure of the model parameters. Our results show that flavour-dependent Type II leptogenesis can provide a viable explanation for the observed baryon asymmetry in the universe. We discuss the implications of our findings for future experimental tests of leptogenesis mechanisms and the search for new physics beyond the Standard Model.
human_text: In the type II seesaw mechanism, in addition to thetype I seesaw contribution, an additional direct mass term for the lightneutrinos is present. We consider type II seesaw scenarios where thisadditional contribution arises from the vacuum expectation value of a Higgstriplet, and furthermore an effective model-independent approach. Weinvestigate bounds on the flavour-specific decay asymmetries, on the mass ofthe lightest right-handed neutrino and on the reheat temperature of the earlyuniverse, and compare them to the corresponding bounds in the type I seesawframework. We show that while flavour-dependent thermal type II leptogenesisbecomes more efficient for larger mass scale of the light neutrinos, and thebounds become relaxed, the type I seesaw scenario for leptogenesis becomes moreconstrained. We also argue that in general, flavour-dependent effects cannot beignored when dealing with leptogenesis in type II seesaw models.

direct_prompt: This study presents spectropolarimetric observations of the Ca II 8498 Å and 8542 Å lines in the quiet Sun, using data obtained from a solar telescope. The aim of this research is to investigate the magnetic properties of the quiet Sun region by analyzing the polarization signals of these calcium lines. The observations reveal the presence of magnetic fields in the photosphere of the quiet Sun, with varying strengths and geometries. By comparing the observed polarization signals with theoretical models, we are able to infer the properties of the magnetic fields in this region. Our findings suggest that the magnetic fields in the quiet Sun exhibit complex and dynamic behavior. Further studies with higher resolution and sensitivity are needed to fully understand the role of magnetic fields in the solar atmosphere.
human_text: The Ca II infrared triplet is one of the few magnetically sensitivechromospheric lines available for ground-based observations. We presentspectropolarimetric observations of the 8498 A and 8542 A lines in a quiet Sunregion near a decaying active region and compare the results with a simulationof the lines in a high plasma-beta regime. Cluster analysis of Stokes V profilepairs shows that the two lines, despite arguably being formed fairly close,often do not have similar shapes. In the network, the local magnetic topologyis more important in determining the shapes of the Stokes V profiles than thephase of the wave, contrary to what our simulations show. We also find thatStokes V asymmetries are very common in the network, and the histograms of theobserved amplitude and area asymmetries differ significantly from thesimulation.

direct_prompt: The thin film geometry introduces unique challenges due to the reduced dimensionality and material interfaces. We investigate the magnetization profile, exchange interactions, and magnetic anisotropy energy of the thin film using both methods. Our results show that Green function theory accurately reproduces the magnetic properties of the film, but Quantum Monte Carlo calculations provide more precise predictions in certain cases. The computational cost and complexity of each method are also compared to evaluate their practical utility for modeling thin magnetic films. Overall, our findings contribute to the ongoing discussion on the most appropriate theoretical approach for studying the behavior of nanoscale magnetic systems. Future research could further explore the potential synergies between Green function theory and Quantum Monte Carlo calculations to improve the accuracy and efficiency of thin film simulations.
human_text: In this work we compare numerically exact Quantum Monte Carlo (QMC)calculations and Green function theory (GFT) calculations of thin ferromagneticfilms including second order anisotropies. Thereby we concentrate on easy planesystems, i.e. systems for which the anisotropy favors a magnetization parallelto the film plane. We discuss these systems in perpendicular external field,i.e. B parallel to the film normal. GFT results are in good agreement with QMCfor high enough fields and temperatures. Below a critical field or a criticaltemperature no collinear stable magnetization exists in GFT. On the other handQMC gives finite magnetization even below those critical values. This indicatesthat there occurs a transition from non-collinear to collinear configurationswith increasing field or temperature. For slightly tilted external fields arotation of magnetization from out-of-plane to in-plane orientation is foundwith decreasing temperature.

direct_prompt: This study investigates competitive nucleation and the Ostwald rule in a generalized Potts model with multiple metastable phases. By analyzing the nucleation behavior of various phases within the model, we aim to understand the conditions under which certain phases dominate the nucleation process. Our results indicate that the nucleation of different phases can compete with each other, leading to the formation of metastable phases that may persist for extended periods of time. Furthermore, we observe that the Ostwald rule, which states that the most stable phase will eventually dominate, may not always hold true in systems with multiple metastable phases. Overall, our findings provide valuable insights into the complex nucleation processes that govern the formation of metastable phases in multi-phase systems.
human_text: We introduce a simple nearest-neighbor spin model with multiple metastablephases, the number and decay pathways of which are explicitly controlled by theparameters of the system. With this model we can construct, for example, asystem which evolves through an arbitrarily long succession of metastablephases. We also construct systems in which different phases may nucleatecompetitively from a single initial phase. For such a system, we present ageneral method to extract from numerical simulations the individual nucleationrates of the nucleating phases. The results show that the Ostwald rule, whichpredicts which phase will nucleate, must be modified probabilistically when thenew phases are almost equally stable. Finally, we show that the nucleation rateof a phase depends, among other things, on the number of other phasesaccessible from it.

direct_prompt: The importance of accurately measuring the CTE of materials intended for use in space environments, especially at low temperatures, is highlighted. The motivation for this research stems from the need for reliable and stable materials in cryogenic space telescopes for precise astronomical observations. A detailed methodology is described for the experimental measurement of the CTE of SiC-100 using a specialized cryogenic setup. The results of the study show a high level of precision in the CTE measurement of SiC-100, with minimal uncertainty. The implications of these findings for the development of cryogenic space telescopes are discussed, emphasizing the potential benefits of using SiC-100 as a material with favorable thermal properties. The challenges and limitations of the measurement process are also addressed, providing insight into areas for future research and improvement.
human_text: The temperature range of the measurements extends from roomtemperature down to $\sim$ 10 K. Three samples, #1, #2, and #3 weremanufactured from blocks of SiC produced in different lots. The thermalexpansion of the samples was measured with a cryogenic dilatometer, consistingof a laser interferometer, a cryostat, and a mechanical cooler. The typicalthermal expansion curve is presented using the 8th order polynomial of thetemperature. For the three samples, the coefficients of thermal expansion(CTE), $\bar{\alpha}_{#1}$, $\bar{\alpha}_{#2}$, and $\bar{\alpha}_{#3}$ werederived for temperatures between 293 K and 10 K. The average and the dispersion(1 $\sigma$ rms) of these three CTEs are 0.816 and 0.002 ($\times 10^{-6}$/K),respectively. No significant difference was detected in the CTE of the threesamples from the different lots. Neither inhomogeneity nor anisotropy of theCTE was observed.

direct_prompt: This paper explores the concept of maximum entropy from the perspective of the principle of virtual work. By considering the system as a whole and analyzing the work done by virtual displacements, a connection is made between entropy and the equilibrium state of a system. Through this framework, a deeper understanding of the relationship between maximum entropy and the principle of virtual work is gained. The implications of this perspective on statistical mechanics and thermodynamics are discussed, shedding light on the fundamental principles governing physical systems.
human_text: We propose an extension of the principle of virtual work of mechanics torandom dynamics of mechanical systems. The total virtual work of theinteracting forces and inertial forces on every particle of the system iscalculated by considering the motion of each particle. Then according to theprinciple of Lagrange-d'Alembert for dynamical equilibrium, the vanishingensemble average of the virtual work gives rise to the thermodynamicequilibrium state with maximization of thermodynamic entropy. This approachestablishes a close relationship between the maximum entropy approach forstatistical mechanics and a fundamental principle of mechanics, and constitutesan attempt to give the maximum entropy approach, considered by many as only aninference principle based on the subjectivity of probability and entropy, thestatus of fundamental physics law.

direct_prompt: In this study, we present NMR evidence for a strong modulation of the Bose-Einstein Condensate in the compound BaCuSi$_2$O$_6. Our nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) measurements reveal a distinct modulation of the condensate, indicating the presence of spatial inhomogeneities in the superfluid density. By analyzing the NMR spectra, we were able to determine the characteristic modulation wavevector and estimate the amplitude of the modulation. Our findings suggest that the modulation in BaCuSi$_2$O$_6$ plays a significant role in the behavior of the Bose-Einstein Condensate in this material. Overall, our results provide valuable insights into the nature of superfluidity in this compound.
human_text: We present a $^{63,65}$Cu and $^{29}$Si NMR study of the quasi-2D coupledspin 1/2 dimer compound BaCuSi$_2$O$_6$ in the magnetic field range 13-26 T andat temperatures as low as 50 mK. NMR data in the gapped phase reveal that below90 K different intra-dimer exchange couplings and different gaps($\Delta_{\rm{B}}/\Delta_{\rm{A}}$ = 1.16) exist in every second plane alongthe c-axis, in addition to a planar incommensurate (IC) modulation. $^{29}$Sispectra in the field induced magnetic ordered phase reveal that close to thequantum critical point at $H_{\rm{c1}}$ = 23.35 T the average boson density$\bar{n}$ of the Bose-Einstein condensate is strongly modulated along thec-axis with a density ratio for every second plane$\bar{n}_{\rm{A}}/\bar{n}_{\rm{B}} \simeq 5$. An IC modulation of the localdensity is also present in each plane.

direct_prompt: This article presents a theoretical framework for describing the flow of quark-gluon plasma (QGP) in 2+1 dimensions using causal dissipative hydrodynamics. The QGP, a state of matter with deconfined quarks and gluons, is expected to exhibit fluid-like behavior. The proposed framework incorporates dissipative effects such as viscosity and thermal conductivity, which may play a crucial role in determining the QGP's transport properties. By considering the system as a viscous fluid with thermal gradients, the model aims to provide a more comprehensive understanding of QGP dynamics. The framework's predictions could have implications for experimental observations of QGP in heavy-ion collisions at facilities such as the Large Hadron Collider. Overall, this work contributes to the ongoing efforts to characterize the properties of QGP and understand the fundamental interactions governing its behavior.
human_text: In 2nd order causal dissipative theory, space-time evolution of QGP fluid isstudied in 2+1 dimensions. Relaxation equations for shear stress tensors aresolved simultaneously with the energy-momentum conservation equations.Comparison of evolution of ideal and viscous QGP fluid, initialized under thesame conditions, e.g. same equilibration time, energy density and velocityprofile, indicate that in a viscous dynamics, energy density or temperature ofthe fluid evolve slowly, than in an ideal fluid. Cooling gets slower asviscosity increases. Transverse expansion also increases in a viscous dynamics.For the first time we have also studied elliptic flow of 'quarks' in causalviscous dynamics. It is shown that elliptic flow of quarks saturates due tonon-equilibrium correction to equilibrium distribution function, and can not bemimicked by an ideal hydrodynamics.

direct_prompt: The hypervolume indicator is a widely used metric for quantifying the quality of Pareto approximation sets in multi-objective optimization problems. Existing algorithms for calculating the hypervolume indicator can be computationally expensive and time-consuming. In this study, we propose a novel algorithm that efficiently computes the hypervolume indicator of Pareto approximation sets. The algorithm is based on the decomposition of the hypervolume into subvolumes, which are then aggregated to obtain the final hypervolume value. We demonstrate the effectiveness and efficiency of our algorithm through experiments on various benchmark problems. Our results show that the proposed algorithm outperforms existing methods in terms of computational complexity and accuracy in calculating the hypervolume indicator.
human_text: Hypervolume indicator is a commonly accepted quality measure for comparingPareto approximation set generated by multi-objective optimizers. The bestknown algorithm to calculate it for $n$ points in $d$-dimensional space has arun time of $O(n^{d/2})$ with special data structures. This paper presents arecursive, vertex-splitting algorithm for calculating the hypervolume indicatorof a set of $n$ non-comparable points in $d>2$ dimensions. It splits outmultiple child hyper-cuboids which can not be dominated by a splittingreference point. In special, the splitting reference point is carefully chosento minimize the number of points in the child hyper-cuboids. The complexityanalysis shows that the proposed algorithm achieves $O((\frac{d}{2})^n)$ timeand $O(dn^2)$ space complexity in the worst case.

direct_prompt: Proteins are essential components of all living organisms, performing a wide range of functions necessary for life. The intricate three-dimensional structures of proteins play a crucial role in determining their functions. One fascinating aspect of protein structure is the presence of intricate knots, where regions of the protein chain are threaded through one another. These knots are thought to play important roles in protein function, stability, and evolution. Understanding the formation and functions of protein knots can provide insights into the evolution of protein structures and their diverse functions. Studies have shown that protein knots can affect protein folding, stability, and catalytic activity. Furthermore, recent research has revealed that certain protein knots are conserved across different species, suggesting that they have been evolutionarily selected for their functional significance.
human_text: A number of recently discovered protein structures incorporate a ratherunexpected structural feature: a knot in the polypeptide backbone. These knotsare extremely rare, but their occurrence is likely connected to proteinfunction in as yet unexplored fashion. Our analysis of the complete ProteinData Bank reveals several new knots which, along with previously discoveredones, can shed light on such connections. In particular, we identify the mostcomplex knot discovered to date in human ubiquitin hydrolase, and suggest thatits entangled topology protects it against unfolding and degradation by theproteasome. Knots in proteins are typically preserved across species andsometimes even across kingdoms. However, we also identify a knot which onlyappears in some transcarbamylases while being absent in homologous proteins ofsimilar structure. The emergence of the knot is accompanied by a shift in theenzymatic function of the protein.

direct_prompt: In this study, we explore the concept of geometrically engineering the Standard Model by locally unfolding three families out of the E8 exceptional Lie group. By analyzing the structure of E8 and its relation to particle physics, we propose a novel method for mapping the dynamics of particle interactions onto a geometric framework. Our approach involves manipulating the geometry of E8 in a way that isolates three distinct families of particles, corresponding to the known generations in the Standard Model. Through this geometric engineering, we aim to provide a deeper understanding of the origins and relationships between the fundamental particles in the universe.
human_text: This paper extends and builds upon the results of an earlier paper, in whichwe described how to use the tools of geometrical engineering to deformgeometrically-engineered grand unified models into ones with lower symmetry.This top-down unfolding has the advantage that the relative positions ofsingularities giving rise to the many `low energy' matter fields are related byonly a few parameters which deform the geometry of the unified model. Andbecause the relative positions of singularities are necessary to compute thesuperpotential, for example, this is a framework in which the arbitrariness ofgeometrically engineered models can be greatly reduced. In our earlier paper, this picture was made concrete for the case ofdeforming the representations of an SU(5) model into their Standard Modelcontent.

direct_prompt: This study investigates the temporal evolution of step-edge fluctuations in a metal thin film under electromigration conditions. Using in-situ scanning tunneling microscopy, the authors track the morphology changes at the step edges over time. The results show that electromigration-induced surface diffusion leads to increased step-edge fluctuations as a function of time. The observed evolution of step edges is attributed to the mass transport of adatoms along the step edges. The study provides insights into the dynamic behavior of step edges under electromigration conditions, which is relevant for understanding the reliability of nanoscale electronic devices. Overall, these findings contribute to the fundamental understanding of electromigration effects on surface morphology evolution.
human_text: The temporal evolution of step-edge fluctuations under electromigrationconditions is analysed using a continuum Langevin model. If theelectromigration driving force acts in the step up/down direction, andstep-edge diffusion is the dominant mass-transport mechanism, we find thatsignificant deviations from the usual $t^{1/4}$ scaling of the terrace-widthcorrelation function occurs for a critical time $\tau$ which is dependent uponthe three energy scales in the problem: $k_{B}T$, the step stiffness, $\gamma$,and the bias associated with adatom hopping under the influence of anelectromigration force, $\pm \Delta U$. For ($t < \tau$), the correlationfunction evolves as a superposition of $t^{1/4}$ and $t^{3/4}$ power laws. For$t \ge \tau$ a closed form expression can be derived. This behavior isconfirmed by a Monte-Carlo simulation using a discrete model of the stepdynamics.

direct_prompt: This article presents a detailed analysis of the azimuthal structure of nuclear collisions. We investigate the distribution of particle production as a function of azimuthal angle in high-energy nuclear collisions. Our analysis reveals a preferential alignment of particles along certain azimuthal angles, indicating the presence of collective flow in the system. Through the study of azimuthal correlations, we provide insights into the dynamics of the collision process and the properties of the produced matter. These findings contribute to our understanding of the complex interplay between geometry, dynamics, and interactions in nuclear collisions.
human_text: We describe azimuth structure commonly associated with elliptic and directedflow in the context of 2D angular autocorrelations for the purpose of preciseseparation of so-called nonflow (mainly minijets) from flow. We extend theFourier-transform description of azimuth structure to include power spectra andautocorrelations related by the Wiener-Khintchine theorem. We analyze severalexamples of conventional flow analysis in that context and question therelevance of reaction plane estimation to flow analysis. We introduce the 2Dangular autocorrelation with examples from data analysis and describe asimulation exercise which demonstrates precise separation of flow and nonflowusing the 2D autocorrelation method. We show that an alternative correlationmeasure based on Pearson's normalized covariance provides a more intuitivemeasure of azimuth structure.
